output: Mr. President, dear colleagues, I apologize once again for my delay.
This year celebrates the European Year of Intercultural Dialogue.
The involvement of all and the perception that education, knowledge and the interweaving of different cultures with each other is crucial is already a fact given as acquired.
Therefore, multiple initiatives related to this year have been carried out by the different areas of action and intervention.
In this context, the Erasmus Programme also plays its role and in this new perspective, the new ruling is already present.

The Erasmus Mundus Programme is an important contribution to the creation of excellence centres in the EU, which will allow to sustain the escape of Serbs to the EU Forum, as well as it represents a significant role

in the promotion of European values among the third-country nations that come here to study and that find in the Old Continent an unparalleled cultural and linguistic diversity that works as an attractive and distinct pole of existing models in the rest of the world.
However, dialogue and interculturality have been enough to survive.

The problem of the visits to students from around the world and the frequent difficulties in obtaining and renewing them leads them to live, many times, in a semi-clandestine situation in the European Union, where they attend master's exams but with tourist visits and, sometimes, cut-off.
I consider it of the greatest importance and urgency to seek a solution that allows for the solidity, transparency and efficiency of the emissions of the pre-exceding waste.
Also the knowledge of the language, which allows cultural perception and mutual coexistence, beyond the strictly academic domain, is crucial, because we can guarantee this absolute permission.
Finally, a word of thanks to the Deputy Dessart Nes, for the way she conducted this whole process and for the balanced report she produced.

Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, dear colleagues, the authorization for the concession of state aid to modernize and renew fishing fleets in the ultra-peripheral regions should be possible only until the end of 2009 or should be in force for an indefinite time.
The particularities of fishing activities in these regions, justify that these aids can be granted beyond 2009, without the marine environment being minimally damaged.
State aid to modernize and renew the fleets in the ultra-peripheral regions for an indefinite time does not mean permanent and eternal aid.
would be immediately interrupted if the studies and evaluation of the Scientific Council and the Regional Consultative Councils evidenced this need.
This is the solution that would best adapt to the very specific reality of the fishing of ultra-peripheral regions.

The same reasons that are fundamental for the fishermen of each RUP, an exclusive fishing reserve up to 100 miles, also justify a differentiated treatment relative to the help for the modernization and renewal of the fleet.
Fortunately, the best solutions were found at the fishing commission headquarters, which can address the particularities of fishing in the regions or the peripheries.

Thank you very much, Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner Almunia, Mr. President of Eurogrupo. I want to congratulate not only the rapporteurs but also the Commission for the initiative of having made this text, the balance of the 10 years of the Economic and Monetary Union.
It is a strategic text and this analysis was fundamental.
The Euro, as it was said here today, is an undeniable success.

from Lisbon to Helsinki, from Dublin to Bratislava, the Euro gave proof of resistance and solidity even during the severe turbulence we witnessed and it is clear that the borders of this club are widened.
but the times that go by put the solidity of the European project in many other dimensions to the test every day.
The Euro, as I said, is a central instrument of the financial system.

However, the text of the Commission clearly points to the fundamental conclusion that neither the growth of the real economy nor the convergence, in terms of both social and spatial, followed this success.
On the contrary, the Commission clearly concludes that disparities have been aggravated in a violent way during the decade of the operation of the single currency.
This divergence affects regions of my country, particularly the north of Portugal, but also other member countries.

The impacts of the single monetary policy, namely the very high rate of exchange practiced, reached more the regions that are more exposed to international competition and the most exploitative regions.
Today, the crisis that resulted from the deregulation of the financial markets, violently affects the real economy and even more aggravates the situation of many citizens and many regions.

These regions, which are exposed to international competition, which depend on small and medium-sized companies, those in which access to credit is more important, are today victims of this process and even threaten to put pressure on them.
Mr. Commissioner, Mr. President of Eurogroup, the success of the Euro depends on the confidence that European citizens deposit in it.
The most powerful European countries have already started a process of relaunching the national economy.
We have the case in particular of initiatives that concern the automotive industry.
But in Europe it is more than that.
must be much more than the more or less coordinated summatory of national policies.
It is time to transform the Euro in a central tool of Europe, supporting a robust currency, but also a robust real economy and to make follow the functioning of the Euro
of mechanisms that guarantee the central objective of achieving social and regional convergence because it is at the core of the European project.
The debate on the coordination of economic policies in the Euro area has an impact and a reforced and unquestionable current.
But coordinating national policies is not enough.
We need more.

Having a Lisbon Strategy, which is a sum of national initiatives and a pact of stability and growth, which differentiates the different countries that use it and that it has to subject to, are limitations to which the budget we set is limited.
Crises generate opportunities.

The monetary union can only be sustained in a convergence of the well-being of the member countries that integrate it, independently, and of its citizens, independently of the place where they were born.
What other way would we have to mobilize citizens for the single currency?

The Commission must be at the level of its own diagnosis and that is why we anxiously await the concrete proposals that the Commission, on the next 26th of November, will bring to this plenary session and will present to European citizens.

It is essential that, from this crisis, a new phase of the Union is launched, in which the consolidation and strength of the financial system are accompanied by an effective prosperity made of cohesion and also economic citizenship.

Thank you Mr. President, Madam Commissioner, dear colleagues. This oral question presented to the European Commission by Gerardo Galeota on behalf of the Regional Development Commission of this Parliament has all the justification and relevance.

In fact, it should be made clear the reasons that lead the Council to block the reform of the Solidarity Fund, as it is not able to reach an agreement on a common position that allows the continuation of the legislative process.
The reasons that may be subjacent to the position of the Council are hardly discussed, except perhaps for petty financial reasons.
Don't you want the Council to provide a more agile and immediate response to the natural disasters that occur?
I do not want the Council to give this type of response to other types of disasters, such as serious industrial accidents, terrorist attacks or serious public health situations.

It is important that these issues have a clear answer, as it is also important to clarify what the European Commission thinks of this situation and if it intends to take any measure intended to unlock the legislative process.
The value of solidarity must also be fully realized in this domain.
citizens would not understand at all if it were not for me.

I just want to say that I wanted to protest against the declaration that was made by Mrs. Luling, who intends to condition the vote of the deputies in this House and this conditioning does not make sense.

The interpretation that is being made is one that we do not share and it is only in this sense that I would like to ask my colleagues who know what they are dealing with, who know that we are defending other interests, which are the interests of public health and the interests of citizens and the interests of countries, to vote in favour of the report. Thank you very much.
Mr. President, Mrs. Commissioner, it has been two months since the political and media agenda has been dominated by the economic and financial crisis.
The referendum in Ireland or the difficulties in the Czech Republic over the Lisbon Treaty are almost not in the media.

Don't you think that now the Commission's information and communication strategy should be reinforced with the need and urgency to enter into force the Lisbon Treaty, also as a political response to face and overcome the crisis we are living in?
Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, dear colleagues, the world powers have at this time under their control the international financial system.
looking for a hand detail and it was no longer without time.
And so, maybe it's time to solve another problem we've heard about decades ago.
We have been listening to this music for decades, of the ignoble plunder of resources, many times, as now in Congo, about the blood of the populations.

I believe that it is time to persecute these companies, to persecute this ignoble trade, to freeze the accounts where the profits of this exploration of mineral resources are deposited, at the expense of the blood and suffering of the populations.
I don't understand why these companies are not listed under the same title that we already have a blacklist of terrorist organizations.
and I don't understand why the international community is not able to persecute these businessmen, who are not businessmen, but real bandits who cause regional and global security.
I encourage the French Presidency and the Commission to lead an international initiative in this regard. Thank you.
We hear here several times today that a crisis usually generates an opportunity, and so it is.
And if we want to take advantage of the opportunity that is open to us, the agenda is easy to know.
First of all, we know, at the European Union level, the need we have to introduce mechanisms of transparency, regulation and supervision in the financial markets.
And it is not necessary that Commissioner Macrivi launches more consultations, nor is it necessary that the Presidency analyses and evokes more studies
Just look at the proposals that were made by the Socialists and that many of them ended up being taken back by this Parliament.
Secondly, Europe cannot be in the international space passively.

It must be an active agent in the construction of the new international order. It must be the defender of a new architecture that does not leave black holes in the system, as are the tax havens at this moment.
Third, we heard today the President of the Commission say that there is a reluctance in the coordination of strategies at the level of the different States.
It is true that if we had not heard from many members of the Commission for so long that markets self-regulate, that the State must stay out
that the financial markets have no impact on growth or employment, perhaps there would be a spirit of solidarity more active and more active at the level of the different countries.
But today, the proposal we have in our hands is a proposal that does not go beyond a first step. If we compare it with China's and the United States' program, on the other hand,
does not define clearly enough what the objective is, and the objective has to be employment and, third, because a European program cannot be a summary of national agendas.
Today is the time to show the citizens of Europe that Europe is a network of economic rights that protects them in times of crisis in terms of
of growth program and support to small and medium-sized companies that are not receiving the results of the interventions that were made at the bank level.
The real economy is that. And we are here as Europeans to show the citizens that Europe is here too and above all because of them. Thank you very much.
Mr. President, dear colleagues, it is with particular satisfaction that I present myself before you to expose the work done in conjunction with everyone in this initiative report.
For me and for everyone who helped to unwind this process, we can say that we did our job.

to all, in particular to the colleagues of the shadow rapporteurs of the different political groups that have made great efforts to achieve future commitments, to the regional development staff always available, namely to Miguel Tell Cremades and Elisa da Farra,

to the staff of the PSC, to Lila and Petros, to the European Commission, who, always being represented by the many and diverse general directions that such a broad report requires, has been permanently and closely monitoring the works and has very much committed to get them to a good port.
To my office, and in particular to Joana Benzinho, to all of you, my sincere thanks in the name of a more harmonious and structured development for coastal regions and tourism in the European Union.
The 27 member states of the European Union add up to 89,000 km of coastal zones.
This one has a variety of very particular characteristics that, according to its location, are characterized by cosmopolitanism, if we talk about cities like Lisbon, Copenhagen or Stockholm,

due to the difficulties of being in peripheral or ultra-peripheral regions, with problems of connection to large cities or with accelerated desertification contexts such as Algarve, Liguria, the Canary Islands or Madeira.
In one way or another, everyone identifies with the notion of coast and coastal zone and lives daily the advantages and disadvantages that are associated with it.
According to the data available, until 2010, about 75% of humanity will live in coastal areas. These areas
According to the circuits and relations between them, we defined as the 50 km in straight line that go from the coastline to the interior zones.
Yes, regions and not maritime sections, detached from an integrated vision, which these matters so much lack and which our ancestors would also describe.
Here, the entire population will concentrate in search of opportunities and economic synergies, and in many cases, having only as an expectation that they will act around tourism.
Thus, the evident need for a pragmatic and integrated vision of the impact of tourism in coastal areas took care of our minds and led us to get down to work.

In the current financial crisis, in which the impact on the real economy is becoming increasingly unbearable, tourism appears as a sector with the enormous potential to be directly or indirectly affected in a brutal way.

Regions that, for their development, have a total or overwhelming dependence on this, see their activity as threatened and look to the future with distrust. Especially because tourism is not currently a European Union competence.
However, joint measures should be taken and the spirit in which the Lisbon Treaty was embedded reflects this same tendency.
However, waiting until the moment of the treaty's entry into force to start acting is to wait for the phase in which we will cry over the spilled milk.
The current political and tourist activity and the fragile reality of the regions that depend on it demand from us urgent and effective action.

the fact that these are structurally dependent areas of tourism, as a promoter of employment. Although it is often seasonal employment, this intensive labor activity cannot be trampled in a context of pressure on urban areas and unemployment.

That is why this report that we are bringing to you now, which was already of the greatest opportunity and urgency when the Regional Development Commission of this House decided to promote it, assumes now that it must be seen as a priority for the European Commission and the European Council.

Priority, yes, to the numerous initiatives that it incorporates, as well as those that take its express support and that have already been conveyed by other institutions, on par with the measures taken in the emergency plan

of the Commission, of which I refer to the review of the Globalization Adjustment Fund, in which the issues associated with this sector, which is the shock to which it is subject at this moment, must obviously be covered.

It is crucial to ensure the development of new segments of the economy of these coastal areas, ensuring their social and environmental sustainability and promoting the real integration of the different sectoral policies such as the maritime sector, transports,

energy, the cohesion instruments in the field, the new quality product policy that the PAC review incorporates with the announcement of the ELSECHEC report and the new tourist products in these coastal areas, taking into account its crucial contribution to the European economy.
The implementation of a proper and holistic vision for this policy should be a reality soon in the European Union.

And to finish, Mr. President, only with a clear articulation of these instruments and a quick and effective action involving all partners and stakeholders already on the ground, we can ensure that we will have in the European Union a sustainable and future-friendly tourist sector. Thank you very much.
Mr. Commissioner, Mr. Minister, the E-Justice is an important step in the access to law, justice and courts.
I would like to congratulate the initiative, congratulate the rapporteur and the French Presidency.

The E-Justice was one of the projects in debate and it was the goal of Portugal during its presidency to lead the development and realization of the pilot project that will allow all citizens access to services from other member states in a simpler, cheaper, more comfortable and in their own language.
This multilingual portal must be designed to serve citizens and companies that seek legal support and elementary legal advice on legal and trans-border issues.
E-Justice must be coordinated and judged by a responsible unit, which will also coordinate the contributions of the various Member States and their articulation with that responsible unit.
The E-Justice will serve the citizen and strengthen our democracy.
I congratulate you on the launch of the portal in December 2009. Thank you very much.
Mr President, Mr Barroso, colleagues, I congratulate the work of Carlos Coelho, of the Cheddar Martin Ruri and the other Cheddars.
In December 2004, the Council adopted regulations that establish standards for the security devices and biometric data of passport and travel documents issued by Member States.
Now we had to take new steps in the sense of combating child rap and trafficking.
The use of passports by children, according to the principle of one person, one passport, can be a fundamental means of winning this difficult and important fight.
In my country, Portugal, the collection of digital impressions in children from the age of 6 is already a practice with a long tradition, which perhaps therefore does not cause me any objection.
As a defender of European cause, I believe that in this matter it is important to see the harmonization

It reassures me to know that Member States like Portugal, who for many years have defined the minimum age of 6 years to proceed with the collection of digital impressions, will not have to change the national legislation.
I must underline that the security of the passports that are being reinforced today is not exhausted by the existence of passports.

The passport alone corresponds to an increase in the level of security, which goes from the presentation of the necessary documents to the issuance of the passports, followed by the collection of biometric data, to verification and matching in the post of the Transfonteiriços control post.
This report is another step towards affirming the rights of the person and guaranteeing their safety.
Mr. President, first of all I would like to greet the reporter Alexander Lambsdorff and the reporters Sombra, with particular emphasis on Barbara Weiler.
Dear colleagues, I think it is essential to advance in the sense of the integration of the national defense markets and even the strategic coordination of their productions.

We must effectively advance with the specificities and precautions necessary in the sense of applying the essential rules of the internal market to the defense industries, increasing transparency in the contests that are organized and in the contracts that are signed involving the member states of the European Union.
but at the same time we have to help in the development of conditions that allow for greater competitiveness of European equipment and products in the world markets.

Commissioner Macrivi, it seems important to me that this directive can guarantee an advance in the legal framework relating to public contracts in the domains of defense and security, advancing the construction of the

and respecting, obviously, the interests and rights of the Member States, especially in the field of security, namely those that manufacture weapons, ammunition, safety equipment, such as my own country.

Mr. President, I would also underline the dispositions that allow the easiest access of small and medium-sized companies to this market, namely through the improvement of the subcontracting rules and the prospect of advancing in this way with greater impact and depth in the decision

industrial development for the creation of a real European market in the defense industries, which can also contribute to strengthen research and development not only in defense industries but in a set of European industries that are part of the development of defense industries.
Finally, I think we can refer to the obvious articulation between the industrial and defense industries of the EU.
But I would like to quote a recent intervention about the debt, translating a classic Roman saying, if you want peace, prepare the war.

The European Union, as it is almost a pacific superpower, we call these industries defense industries and not war industries, because we want peace and not war, and that's why we need defense industries.
Mr. Vice President Barroso, I agree with you on the dissatisfaction
In fact, we have to be satisfied with the set of measures that are vast.
The truth is that irregular immigration continues to Europe, human trafficking continues, there are areas where there is a lot of
namely the Mediterranean and in the direction of Italy. France has advanced with a set of important bilateral cooperations, but other member states have not.
It is necessary that the Commission continues without losing enthusiasm in this policy of cooperation and help to the United States.
President, Madam Commissioner, I will try to put the issues in a very synthetic way.
First point, the issue of the special monitoring mechanism of the European Union for the tests that ended, as it was said here, on December 31, 2008.
It is necessary, Madam Commissioner, the timely and routine publication of statistical data on imports, exports and prices, similar to what happens in the United States.
Without this data, the European Union is unable to react against any illegal practices and the Commission itself is unable to define its strategy.
I asked him for attention to this, in the same way that other colleagues have done.
Secondly, producing within the European Union, forces us to comply with safety, social and environmental standards.
RITS, for example, is a recent initiative that creates even more conditioning for us.
It is important that the Commission has a clear strategy and that it is perceptible and passable to monitor so that imported products have identical requirements.
How are the free trade agreements in progress and are these aspects being properly taken into account?
And what about Meydine? Can Meydine help to solve this issue?
Third point. The European Union has launched a plan of economic recovery to combat the current crisis.
What role will commercial policy play in this context?

At this moment, what is the Commission preparing to do when a number of other countries, such as China, start to proliferate the launch of non-tariff barriers, increasingly, so that our European imports do not access Chinese markets?

What is the proposal regarding the update or adjustment of the fund for globalization, as well as the support available in the framework of structural funds to improve the immediate situation of the textile industry in Europe?
Last question, finally, in fact, will the crisis we are going through finally make the Commission sensitive to the devastating impact on the European economy of a euro overvalued?
How can you, Madam Commissioner, raise awareness, I'm ending now, raise awareness of your colleagues and the entities that deal with European monetary policy in the sense of rebalancing? Thank you.
For us, it is clear that we must applaud the Obama decision, the decision to end Guantanamo, the prohibition of the torture of illegal interrogations and the suspension of military processes.
However, dear colleague who is no longer present, Portugal and the Portuguese Socialist Government have no guilt.
The Portuguese Socialist Government did not collaborate with the Bush administration, quite the opposite.

It was precisely now with the Portuguese administration, with the Portuguese government, with the initiative of Minister Luís Amado that the possibility and the duty of the European Union and democratic countries was unleashed to welcome and receive the detainees without a guilty conscience in Guantanamo.

This is what is truly important, this is what should be highlighted as an example to follow by the remaining Member States of the European Union. How important is it that tomorrow the resolution is approved by the group of parties that make up this Chamber, so that in unity the decision can have more strength.
Thank you Mr. President, thank you very much to the colleague Ana Politano for the excellent report.

Fourteen years after Barcelona and five years after the first Euro-Mediterranean Parliamentary Assembly, we have the Union for the Mediterranean, with economic power, with parliamentary power, with civil society, with government leaders to decide together.
All of them with the will to do more and better in a territory where 720 million citizens represent the potential for development and peace for the world.
Only keeping them on the economic and business side is a clear mistake.

Responding to the growth crises requires, naturally, political response. But responding to humanitarian crises, emergency situations and military crises, as we experienced in late 2008 and early 2009, is crucial.
Politicians and citizens must give answers to the world's problems.
The world asked for answers and months later we still continue, citizens and politicians, designated on a platform like the Mediterranean Union, to delay to react.
I hope that at least this moment has served to learn and move forward, because only those who make mistakes learn. But moving forward in the speed of reaction is absolutely crucial.
The interest of approving this directive is essentially in the way it can contribute to dynamize economic activity in the local plan and support actions in the social plan.
This application of a reduced rate has great importance in the domain of housing, both in construction and in renovation, allowing the Member States to reduce the respective cost to the end user.

The provision of local services, namely by small-scale companies, can also be benefited by this reduction in the VAT rate, ensuring and generating more and better employment through the promotion of the consumption of goods and services, thus stimulating the economy itself.
The restoration activity, fundamental for the good functioning of local economies and the increase of tourism itself, can thus gain a lot in the local plan with this reduction of the IVA tax.
These services, dear colleagues, should not circulate in the European internal market, which will help to reduce the reserves of some Member States already verified in the Council's plan.
Therefore, I cannot agree with the extension of this reduced rate of equipment, whatever the protest.

The prudent way in which this proposal should be treated in the European Parliament should not give pretext to governments that have some reservations regarding the proposal of the European Commission to use in practice the right to veto that European legislation still discontents in fiscal matters.
Thus, we must reject changes that only make it difficult to accept the text.
As already mentioned here, not only the great is the enemy of the good, but whoever wants everything, loses everything.
This Directive proposal is important not only for the strengthening of local economies, but also for the repeated ambitions expressed by various Member States.
We then supported the Commission's proposal as it was presented. This was, in fact, the purpose of the vote, as is the agreement of the Commission of the Internal Market in Protection of Consumers.

I salute the work of the rapporteurs and appeal to approve this proposal in the exact terms in which it came from the Commission and was voted in the Parliamentary Commission of the Internal Market in Protection of Consumers. Thank you very much.
I had the word to disagree with my colleague Edith Estrela, and that was what motivated me to speak, when she caricatured the intentions of the Czech presidency.
No one wants to send their wives home. The problem is that there are women who want or would like to stay home.
There are even associations that try to defend them. Women who are ignored, despised, discriminated because they want to dedicate themselves to the family and we don't listen to them.
And this is a matter of freedom, a matter of freedom of choice, which the Left likes to evoke so much but forgets here.
It is about respecting or not the freedom of the orientation of couples.
It is about being able to provide those who want to do it this way, more quality of life, more paternity and more quality of motherhood.
This is what our society also needs to do.
We will not go there, we will not solve the problems of birth and happiness of people with prejudice.
We resolve with policies that are aligned with the reality and the spontaneous desires of people.
We are not going there with an obsession with the State and with the market.
Let's go there with a fair look on the family.
The difficult situation in Quimonda was aggravated by the emergency of the financial and economic crisis.
The Portuguese Government has done everything it can to help resolve the situation.
and we would like the Bavarian Government to know how to act with great sense of responsibility in this domain.
Saving the Munich facilities will have a decisive impact on the units Vila do Conde and Dresden.

The Portuguese Minister himself, Manuel Pinho, stated his great interest in making this company so important to Portugal and Europe, referring to the fact that AkiMonda can be a competitive company worldwide.
President, keeping the efforts of the Government of Portugal in the sense of a solution that guarantees the company's viability
We hope that the German governments, in the federal and state plan, will effectively take action in resolving this problem.
As for me, I would like to underline again the strategic importance of maintaining this type of industry in European territory.
that no national or state executive commits the mistake of allowing this company to close its facilities and liquidate jobs in the territory of the Union.

Dear colleagues, we understand the need to help the restructuring of the large Groups of Automobile Industry, but the Union Funds and the energies of the European Commission cannot be wasted on these aids.

Dear Commissioner, to put the Commission in support of Quimonda, overcoming the possible communication failures, is the appeal we make to Commissioner Vladimir Spidla, to whom we link ties of work and political solidarity, and to President Barroso, who will never forget that he is our compatriot and a significant part of Quimonda's workers.

We must highlight, before ending, that the Portuguese President, Cavaco Silva, in Germany, recently stated that there was a new hope for Quimonda. And, even if we refer to the importance, as has been done by colleagues, of the economic sector itself in which Quimonda operates,
We are aware of this, so that the Portuguese government is available to support Quimonda with whatever is necessary, serving the economic dimension of the country.
Ladies and gentlemen, let's help save Quimonda. The time is now.

Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, we have been talking about the Lisbon Strategy for years. And the times we have lived are not the right times to talk about the Lisbon Strategy, but we certainly need a strategy.
a strategy that responds to the difficulties and challenges that the present crisis poses.
And that is what we expect from the Commission.
It is essential that the Commission does not move away from this subject and that it has the capacity to articulate actions with the governments of Portugal, Germany and the German Lenders.

It is essential to bear in mind that this is an industry, as has been said here, that interests Europe, for its quality and value, for the research it develops, for the environmental quality also associated with it. And it is essential that the Commission does not move away.
I subscribe the invitation made by my colleague Peneda for the Commissioner and the Commission to move to Portugal.

It is essential that the Commission has in mind that at this time the Europeans are looking at Europe and expect answers from the European authorities. They need to feel that the European authorities are close.

European citizens do not understand a Europe that washes hands. They want a Europe that has the audacity to put hands on the table and to put hands to work helping them to overcome difficulties. Thank you.

Mr. President, thank you very much. I also join my words to the homages to Jamounet, but I asked for your word to greet the President for the declaration he made on the European Day in memory of the victims of terrorism.
It was through my proposal, which we adopted five years ago, that the Council established, in a meeting on March 25, following the tragic attacks in Madrid,
but my intervention was a call

The Parliament has always been faithful to the celebration of this date, but unfortunately this date has not yet had, in the group of European institutions and Member States, the projection it should have.
I believe that the celebration of this date is one of the most important instruments we have to honor the victims, as Mr. President did, but also to raise the level of awareness of public opinion.
I know that there are some celebrations in Madrid today, but not much more.
Therefore, my appeal to the Commission and the Czech Presidency is that all Member States celebrate this date in the future. Thank you.
Ladies and gentlemen, dear colleagues, the crisis is deeper than we expected and unemployment will be greater than we expected.
There are good reasons to assume that the European stimulus is not enough. But it is clear that it is taking too long to reach citizens.
The position of the Parliament is strong and clear. It has been and I hope it will continue to be.
Our objective is to maintain employment and create new jobs with solidarity, both territorial and social.
And in this moment of crisis, citizens cannot be satisfied with a Europe that does not give them an answer, with a Europe that is impotent in the face of the problems they are going through.
What will the Parliament ask the Commission?

Naturally, through these reports, he asks for national interventions. He asks that he use all means available to intervene and that he give all the conditions as an budgetary entity for this to happen.

asks him to launch a clear European initiative for employment and tells him that it is important to have a calendar agenda to implement the measures of regulation of the financial market, as well as to reach the real economy with credit.
But what do you ask the council?
I ask the Council to, above all, re-encounter the political will that is at the core of the construction of the European project.
The European Union is competition, but it is also cohesion and solidarity.
And there can be no single market without this guarantee. Solidarity and cohesion.
That is why we all delegated at the European level the national autonomy we had before joining this project. Thank you very much.

Mrs. President, Mrs. Commissioner, those who visit sub-Saharan Africa easily recognize the enormous weakness of their health systems and the extremely negative impact that this weakness has on the life and health of the populations that those services should serve.
The indicators continuously disclosed at an international level do not cease to confirm it.
And in this measure it is absolutely disturbing the notion that simple and practical gestures, not even very elaborate, not even particularly expensive, could be enough to save many lives.

European financial support can be crucial in this regard and we cannot fail to keep in mind how cooperation in the health sector is truly strategic and goes directly beyond not only one of the goals of the millennium, but many of the goals of the millennium.

The Court of Accounts considered that, I quote, the community funding in favor of the health sector has not increased since 2000 in proportion to its total help to development, despite the compromises made by the Commission on the objectives of the Millennium and the health crisis in sub-Saharan Africa.
End quote.

and recognized, I quote again, the Commission contributed significantly through its funding to form the World Fund for the Fight Against AIDS, Tuberculosis and Malaria, but did not give the same attention to the reinforcement of health systems that was expected to be one of its priorities.
End quote.

According to the Court, this will happen again because the Commission did not have enough experience in the field of health to ensure that the funding for the help granted to this sector was used in the best way.
End quote.
This is therefore a strong challenge that the Court of Auditors launches directly to the European Commission and that I follow.
On our part, I want to reiterate this same challenge, now supported in the objectivity of this data and this assessment.
Health services are already part of it, but they must be increasingly part of our priorities of help and development, being worthy of an increase in their funding.

Optimizing the way help is provided, having in mind the apparently antagonistic needs of coordination in its management and proximity with the beneficiary populations, is providing a service that can save many lives.
The European Commission cannot fail to respond positively to this request and in this sense I exhort it.
Colleague Bois recently gave us a touching intervention and was able to put human faces in the dry cold of these numbers of the Court of Auditors.
The challenge for us, Madam Commissioner, is that our cooperation is able to put in these very faces a look of joy and hope.
And for that, Madam Commissioner, it is essential that the numbers in the health sector in our cooperation are different.
Mr. President, Madam Commissioner, dear colleagues, once again, for sad reasons, we discuss here the situation of Bissau, which is a truly painful situation.
It is a country that has been living in chronic instability for many years, that has been trying to achieve democracy in the early 90's,

Nothing went well, there was a coup d'état, a small internal war, and they live in great instability. Politics, military, tensions, deep rivalries, and now recently also the very worrying presence, increasingly evident to all observers, of the interest of drug trafficking.
We vigorously condemn these attacks, the death to the bomb of the Chief of State, Tagumena Aue, and also the murder, in particularly barbaric terms, not to say savage, of President Nino Vieira
regardless of their past, we express our solidarity to their families, to the people of Guinea-Bissau and we lament, we severely condemn these attacks.
We wish the return to normality. And the lesson I draw from it, and that I would like to highlight in the resolution, is that impunity is not a remedy.
In the past, regarding the murder of Suman Mané and General Veríssimo Seabra, how did you close your eyes to the fact that the guilty were not found and taken to justice?
it is obvious that this is not the solution.
Therefore, we must make it clear to the state of Guinea-Bissau that the responsible must be found, the guilty must be brought to justice and we must provide all the necessary help.

I would also like to draw attention to the concern we saw about the presence of the NAD with the traffic in the whole region, the risk that this represents also for the European Union and the shocking presence, for its evidence, in Guinea-Bissau.
I would also like to appeal to the fact that if we narrow down the relationship with Cape Verde

We established a special partnership with Cape Verde. Cape Verde has very close relations with Guinea, a great knowledge, but it is also very vulnerable. And this is also essential for our own European security.
Therefore, the intensification of the Special Partnership with Cabo Verde is also very important in this context. Thank you very much.
Mrs President, dear colleagues, I would like to thank you all for the work you have done.

The three lines defined in the Green Book, concentration, interrelation and cooperation, can provide solutions to some obstacles to the harmonious development of the Union, namely the negative effects associated

the concentration of economic activity, inequalities in terms of access to markets and services resulting from the distance and the divisions imposed by the borders between member states, especially the most disadvantaged ones, but also between the regions.
We must promote the improvement of the synergies between these policies with effective evaluation methods of their territorial impact.

That is why, since always, I have been defending the definition of additional qualitative indicators with the aim of improving the conception and execution of the corresponding policies in the field, taking into account the different territorial specificities.
For now, the GDP remains the only eligibility criteria to receive the support of the structural funds.

However, this definition of additional indicators and the implementation of territorial evaluations should not be the result of more bureaucracy or delays, but rather the simplification of the application of new policies and actions to support territorial cohesion.
The fifth report, to end, Mr. President, refers specifically to transition regions, between convergence regions and employment and competitiveness regions.
It is important to note that these regions need a clearer statute, with more security and stability for their development. Thank you.

Thank you, Madam Commissioner, dear colleagues. In the context of this great debate on territorial cohesion and the future of the economic and social cohesion policy, I could not help but mention the very specific problem of the ultra-peripheral regions.

Regions that, by the conjugation and permanence of a number of geographical factors, reveal a great economic and social vulnerability, particularly felt in a context of a serious international crisis such as the one we are currently experiencing.
I would like to appeal to the European Commission and especially to Commissioner Huebner to pay particular attention to the effects of the current crisis in the ultra-peripheral regions.

An assessment of these effects in each of the ultra-peripheral regions, namely in tourism, construction and the increase of unemployment, would be important to provide a specific European response to these regions.

I challenge the European Commission to prepare a European response to the crisis for the ultra-peripheral regions, which goes beyond the measures already announced in the context of the economic and social cohesion policy for the generalities of the European regions.
a European response specific to the crisis for the regions of the Baltic states.

Mr President, dear colleagues, In response to the global financial crisis, the European Economic Relations Plan refers to the fact that the cohesion policy contributes significantly to public investment by member states and regions, which must act as a way of recovering from the current crisis.
It specifically suggests the adoption of actions in priority areas of the Lisbon Strategy, in order to achieve growth and employment.
All instruments engaged seek to achieve this purpose and accelerate the achievement of results.

In this sense, the expansion of the European Fund for Globalization and the agilization of the European Social Fund have a particular responsibility to respond to the multiple situations of social and economic emergency that need support.
I am certain, today as in the past, that your action will be as effective as the more complementary your actions and areas are.

However, as it was not planned to provide new funds or new lines of action in the field, it is particularly important that the European Social Fund be used in all its potential in the fight against unemployment and rapidly increasing the pressure of competitiveness in the European economy, resulting from the current financial crisis and economic weakness.

I would like to underline that the Regi Commission has repeatedly identified simplification as essential for the improvement of the management and implementation of structural funds, as the European Commission now proposes.
An urgent request was sent to us, however, regarding this matter. And in adopting this Regulation, we took it into account. And this cause never refused to assume its political responsibilities.

Therefore, despite many serious views that the particularity of the moment arouses, in addition to the guarantees of the speed of the process and the real benefit for the citizens that the proposal aims, we must now present new proposals and changes.
However, we alert to the need to start from now on a process of evaluation of this fund, with regard to a complementary review to be carried out as soon as possible. Thank you.
The crisis, among other aspects, has allowed to highlight the strong imbalances between the countries in the Eurozone, perhaps the main
the conclusion of the report of the Economic and Monetary Union on 10, but above all the extreme vulnerability of the countries belonging to the European Union do not belong to the Eurozone.

Hence, the reinforcement of the available means at the European level to support crisis situations of the balance of payments is absolutely essential. Hence, we only give the passage from 12 to 25 and hence to 50 million euros of necessary means.
However, the most important thing is to attack the deep causes of the problems and not only their most evident manifestations.
Today, the extended Europe and the Eurozone must reinterpret the sense of European solidarity and the objectives of cohesion and real convergence.
It is necessary to see in this light what is the capacity of the horizontal European policies, but it is also necessary to revisit new financing instruments such as the Eurobonds.
Financial assistance to the payment balance is necessary, but it is far from being enough to guarantee the sustainability of the European project and the European single currency.
Mr. President of the Commission, Mr. President in Existence, we are in a crisis without precedent.

It was not the time to discuss internally how we should organize ourselves. Therefore, my votes are for the Lisbon Treaty to be quickly ratified so that we can face the world scene united and united as Europeans.

Regarding the economic crisis, in the report I was the author of and which this Parliament approved majority, it was admitted that the plan of relaunch, however presented by the Commission, was not enough.
Today we are sure that it is not enough.
A crisis that started financially, extending to the real economy, then to employment and then to social.
It is not enough and it is out of focus.

each crisis closes an opportunity. This is the opportunity for the Commission to respond to the real problems of the Europeans, through a serious financial regulation and not the lighter and partial one
possible, how it is going. Not made of national plans, individualistic, but of a true European initiative. Not through scattered means, but focusing on the real challenge that I employ.

In every crisis there is an opportunity. This is the opportunity of the European Commission to respond to the real problems of European citizens. And I hope that this will happen through a new approach to the relaunch plan. Thank you very much.

Mr. President, dear colleagues, I would like to express, not only on behalf of the PPP, as has been done by many deputies, but in particular on behalf of the Portuguese deputies of the PPP, the great satisfaction with the result of the referendum in Ireland.
We believe that this clearly reinforces the perspectives of development and evolution of the European Union, that creates conditions for a new stage,

We would like to congratulate all those who contributed to the Lisbon Treaty, in particular the Commission and the Vice-President here present, and also, of course, the Portuguese Presidency of the European Union,

had a very important role here. And that is why we want to say that we are very pleased to see that, despite all these vicissitudes, and still to be expected by the Czech Republic, it will be with great joy that the Portuguese will see the name of their capital linked

a decisive step in the evolution of the European Union and I would like to say that we can also compare in this perspective with another flag, which will always be a flag of the Portuguese MPs of the PPP, which is the flag of the national parliaments.
We believe that the Lisbon Treaty is a decisive step in the sense of incorporating the presence of the national parliaments in European democracy.
And so we think that this dimension, which is the most important dimension of democracy, which is the representative dimension, and not, as we hear in this Chamber, the referendary dimension,

fundamental and essential democracy is representation and not direct voting, the Lisbon Treaty is also a great step in the direction of increasing the participation of national representative democracies in the European process.
That is why we are very satisfied with this decision of the Dutch people.

Thank you Mr. President, Mrs. Minister, Mrs. Commissioner, dear colleagues. A brief intervention to solidify the historic and broad result of the referendum in Ireland and to raise the decisive role that Fyne Gael and his leader and next Prime Minister of Ireland, Enda Kenny, were taking to assume the leadership of this process.
a process in which it was well known the need to bring much closer the European Union to its citizens.
They are, we are all, the main recipients of the entire action of the Union.
It is essential that everyone is aware of the impact and benefits that Europe has daily in our lives.
Europe is our vital space.
What is good for Europe is good for each member state, it is good for its citizens.
This is certainly the case with the Lisbon Treaty.
With this treaty, it becomes much more evident that one can simultaneously be a proud and committed citizen and a firm defender of the European project.

And the European Union, closed a too long debate about its organization and operation, will be able to focus much more and with new instruments much more effective on the real problems facing Europeans, competitiveness, growth and employment.
I conclude, Mr. President, Mrs. Minister, with a proposal for future generations.

Considering the information deficit on values, competences, objectives and the way of functioning of the European Union, the European Parliament should propose, at the end of the compulsory school year in each Member State, a new discipline of European studies of compulsory nature.
In an objective, true and concrete way, young Europeans will know our principles, who we are, what we do and where we want to go.

is through the knowledge of young people who will understand throughout their lives the potential and enormous usefulness of European identity in this unique project of voluntary sovereignty on a continental scale.

Thank you Mr. President. Mr. President of the Commission, I begin by congratulating you on this first debate for what this new political control instrument means for the advancement and development of parliamentary democracy in Europe.

There have been diligence by the President of the Commission
and what is the forecast for a possible date of the entry into force of the treaty and, on the other hand, to know if at this moment and according to this forecast the Commission
whether some transitions are already being made from the Nice Treaty to the Treaty of Lisbon, or if it is still in a phase of expectation, in a phase of waiting to see.

is whether we will have, until the moment of final ratification by the Czech Republic, a commission in charge or if they will advance in the procedure of naming the new commissioners.

Thank you Mr. President. It is essential that the primary objective of the creation of the European Service for External Action is to achieve the efforts of European institutions, ensure the creation of an effective service capable of articulating, formulating and implementing a European response to the international challenges of the present.
should represent more than the parties that constitute it. It should be an added value relative to the current efforts of the Member States and the European Union.
In this sense, it seems essential that what makes the Union's specificity is at the center of this new reality. And this specificity is the community method.
That is why I give my full support to the Broc report, which defends and safeguards a close partnership between the Commission and the Future Service.

I created this proposal to highlight two aspects. The importance of a strict coordination between the President of the Commission and the High Representative, also Vice President of the Commission, to ensure its effectiveness and good functioning.

The Parliament must therefore be vigilant and ensure that the European Service for External Action will be a center of excellence, representative of the best competences in matters of external policy.

Thank you, Mr. President, thank you, Mr. Commissioner. First of all, I want to reinforce the importance of this issue that was raised by the Deputy-General, because it is a matter of the most elementary justice.
We all know that in a pandemic situation, the southern countries will suffer the most with this problem and with the consequences of the spread of the virus, and not the northern countries.

And we watch every year with total passivity the death of millions of citizens as a result of pandemics that have either been eradicated or have treatment in the countries of the North. A huge list of malaria, dengue, yellow fever, tuberculosis,
We have no limits for this list and we are watching this problem with passivity.

We use the countries of the South as suppliers, as a free agent, of the samples of the new virus strains to be able to improve the treatment in the countries of the North, but we are without effective response to these problems. And therefore, to the questions that were asked, I would like to add just a few more.
We want to treat this problem as a public health problem or as a business problem.
Because if it is a public health problem, we have to ensure equal access to treatment in all regions of the world and for that the efforts have to be more effective.
On the other hand, I would like to ask, and I hope it is not the case, if we are waiting for the stocks of vaccines in Europe to be over-priced,
that the side effects are so negative in this plan, so that we can have a act of generosity and suddenly start sending the necessary vaccines to the countries of the South.

And finally, I would like to ask if the European Union, if we Europeans and the Commission feel comfortable with a system or a model where the countries of the North treat pandemics through a prevention model and in the countries of the South treat them as palliatives or only with the leftovers.

Thank you, Mr. President. First of all, I want to express my total support for the question that was asked by Mr. Roel and, above all, to highlight the question of fund, the political question of fund that is here in this matter, which has precisely to do with the joint program of research.

What happened in the matter of joint programming on neurodegenerative diseases and in particular on Alzheimer's was that the rules were changed in the middle of the process, we stopped having a report and we started to have a resolution, therefore our capacity for co-decision in this matter was eliminated, we stopped being deputies and we started to be consultants.
and therefore I would like to know if at least what we recommend will be taken into account or not.
Programming research activities, whatever the subject, is a political choice, not a technical choice. In this sense, the role of the Parliament must be valued and reinforced.
It seems to me that defining priorities that are political means that they must be coordinated, that they must be transparent, that they must be democratic.
What happened with the process in relation to the joint decision and the joint program of the investigation on Alzheimer's is a process that should not be repeated again and if it is repeated
I repeat, please let me know in advance. I hope that the last thing that can happen to us is that the decisions and recommendations that the Parliament presented in this matter are not considered.
Mr. Speaker, in the last month the regions of Europe had particular evidence.
The European Week dedicated to regions and cities, has considered the position of regions as a fundamental part of the solution in the European response to global challenges.

The global challenges and European responses constitute a great opportunity for a new strategy for the RUP.

These regions, such as the Azores, in addition to the permanent constraints that everyone is used to hearing about, present a set of potentialities that provide clear opportunities to make our progress and give Europe a clear advantage in new essential domains in response to global challenges.

And I say that the President of the Commission makes a clear end to the Palacian coup that the Commission's no paper indicates that was being prepared while we were making, as European citizens and MPs, the apology for the ratification of the Treaty of Lisbon and its importance in the defense of the cohesion of the European territory.
First of all, I would like to greet the reporters, namely Mr. Martin and Mr. Corbett, and say that as a member of the PPE I basically review the proposed changes to the Regime.
I would like to highlight the point that I find important and that was not brought here tonight, which is the point of the national parliaments.
The democratic reinforcement of the European Parliament is undoubtedly due to this Regime and the Treaty of Lisbon, but European democracy is also due to the link to the national parliaments.
And what this Regime, this proposal, is doing now is precisely to create these two democratic legitimities, to reinforce democracy.

On the one hand, democracy resulting from the instruments of the European Parliament, from its control instruments, from its legislative capacity, and on the other hand, the democratic collaboration of the national parliaments through different instruments.
And that's why I'm here, let's say, totally in tune with the proposals made
I do not agree with my colleague Duff when he understands that we should leave for later the introduction of mechanisms of relationship with the national parliaments.
I think we can do it since the beginning of the Lisbon Treaty and that this is very important.
I would also like to say that I follow the proposal of my colleagues Sayer and Brock regarding the representation at COSAC and, finally, that I am
I am entirely in solidarity with the observations made by my colleague Broc and other colleagues about the primacy of the Parliament and its deputies in relation to the services of the Parliament.

Thank you very much, Mr. President, Mrs. President, Mr. Commissioner, dear colleagues. I congratulate the reporter colleague for the work she has done in this report and for her intervention recently.
This new microfinancing tool will allow the concession of microcredit to small companies and people who have lost their jobs and want to create their own business and their own job.
This is very important in a period in which it is expected that the economic crisis results in the loss of 3.5 million jobs only in the European Union.
As a consequence of the economic slowdown, banks stopped granting loans for the creation of jobs and companies and access to credit is more difficult at a time when it should be more accessible.

This new means of microfinancing will counteract the current tendency of the restriction of access to credit, facilitating the obtaining of funds necessary for the launch of new companies and new jobs.
The European Commission's proposal aims to reaffect the budget of 100 million euros of the Programme Progress for this financing instrument.
We cannot agree with this proposal.
The financial and economic crisis is also a social crisis.
Thus, the reaffecting of the resources of progress aimed at the most vulnerable groups is not the most adequate solution.
For this reason, a separate budget group is being created to finance this instrument, as well as an increase in the amount of 150 million euros.

We also agree with the need to clarify in the legislation itself that the target group are the vulnerable groups that have difficulty entering or re-entering the labor market and that face the threat of social exclusion.
Thus, it must be removed from reference to specific groups.
Finally, we emphasize that it is essential that people who have financial support also have adequate training. Thank you very much.

Thank you very much, Mr. President. I would like to start by congratulating the Swedish Presidency and, in particular, Prime Minister Reinfeldt, both on behalf of the PPP and on behalf of the Portuguese delegation of the PPP.
Our balance of the Swedish Presidency is of an almost absolute success, essentially in four fundamental areas.
The first in the institutional area, the contribution of the Swedish Presidency to the entry into force of the Treaty of Lisbon, to the very successful election of the President of the Commission,
for all the issues related to ratification. It was extremely professional and had, at the level of what is expected, the best practices of the European Union.
Naturally, for a country like Portugal, which played a decisive role in the approval of the Treaty of Lisbon, this contribution of the Swedish Presidency is inestimable.
The second point is the climate agenda, where the work of the Commission was also very important.
We must say that, from the point of view of many MPs of the PPP, it is in the area of climate change that the European Union has had the most success,
is there in the real front of global combat and this is due to the effort of the Swedish Presidency and especially the Commission Presidency
We consider this balance very positive.
The third point is the financial regulation, which, especially with this last Council, has taken a decisive step and which can have a very big impact on the exit of the crisis.
I would like to congratulate them for having achieved an agreement in this area
And finally, I would like to say a few words about an area that personally tells me a lot, which is the Stockholm program and therefore the area of security, justice and freedom.

I believe that I, who followed both the TEMPER process and the DIA process, consider this programme absolutely essential and I would like to congratulate the Swedish Presidency and Prime Minister Reinfeldt for this.

Thank you very much, Mr. President. For the recognition of professional qualifications, 15 directives were consolidated in a single legislative act, as we know, which caused various problems of practice in the application in the different Member States.

The difficulties are known and the Commission will have to invent the critical points and make an analysis of the problematic areas that are present in the application of this important device of the internal market.
The protectionism that manifests itself at various levels is a barrier not only to the free circulation of people but also to the internal market
we must try to identify the nebulous points so that the effectiveness of the directive is not misguided by mistrust.
The Union should not be asked to do what the Member States should do, but there is an effort to facilitate the implementation that helps to break down professional corporativism.
An improvement in the application of this directive will lead to a disclosure of the recognition of qualifications in the Solvit network and in the EURES network, through the incentive
and common platforms, implementation of effective contact points and, not less important, it will provide an articulation of this directive with the services directive.

Thank you very much Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen. It is urgent that a debate be held on the community budget and how it can contribute to its sustainability and transparency in the future.

The financial framework for 2013 must be built on the basis of solidarity and territorial cohesion, crucial values for regions such as Madeira, which face permanent difficulties and therefore need permanent support.
I would like to share with you some ideas that I think should always be present when you think and build a cohesion policy.

The Commission has been referring to, on several occasions, some aspects that seem essential to me, such as the need for greater flexibility, simplicity, efficiency and more guidance for obtaining results in the definition and implementation of this policy.
But there are issues that arouse some concern, especially considering the needs of the ultra-peripheral regions.
In this matter, allow me three short notes. First, the current approach in terms of regions should prevail over alternative orientations such as the added value sectors.

A reorientation like this can, however, cause objective 2, which currently benefits about two thirds of the European regions, in addition to potentially being counterproductive in regions of economic preference and very own competitive advantages. Secondly, it seems to me that the maintenance of the proximity criterion in the cohesion policy is vital.

should continue to privilege the allocation and management of structural funds from a regional and non-national perspective, or even centralised at the European level. Third and last, but not least, I would like to remind and underline article 349
The 349th Lisbon Treaty provides a special treatment of the ultra-peripheral regions in which access to structural funds is touched, precisely due to its economic and social situation
by conditionalism and unique characteristics of perennial character, which manifest themselves in such constant difficulties and therefore require the required permanent assistance. Thank you.
Thank you, Mr. President. Regarding the emergency, what we witnessed in Copenhagen was several steps back.

It is true that Copenhagen mobilized more heads of state than Kyoto, but it also created more divisions. And as a result, what happened was that we started to have a situation of each one for himself, where each state can define what their goals are and even more so in a voluntary regime.
to refer that if we have a 2°C goal or goals for financing without any clarification, it can also not serve as a consolation.
So I think we have to act in terms of the future. And to act in terms of the future is to stop passing from rhetoric to action.
The European Union always wanted to be a leader, it always said so.
But when we arrived in Copenhagen, he hesitated, not to define or defend the goals that he affirmed to be his goals and which he would not deny.

And so, what I ask is whether in the future we will not be more fair, if we will continue to allow that at the expense of this failure and the decisions of some over others, the poorest continue to pay the most expensive bill.
Thank you very much, Mr. President. I would like to denounce here what is happening in Portugal at this moment, where it is clear that social communication
a government plan was brought to light to control newspapers, to control television stations, to control radio stations, which puts in question the freedom of expression.
Even this week, a well-known journalist, Mário Crespo, censored a report of his, also by suggestion or apparent suggestion of the Prime Minister.
For this reason, Prime Minister José Sócrates must give substantial explanations to the country. He must explain that he is not dominating, censoring the freedom of expression in Portugal.

The way we are walking, Portugal is no longer a State of Law, it is a State of Formal Law, where the Prime Minister limits himself to formalities, procedures, formalisms and does not want to give substantial explanations.
For Portugal, we want a material state of law.

Thank you very much Mr. President. The Green Book for the Reform of the Common Policy of Fishing, whose report is my colleague from the Azores, Marido do Seu Patrão Neves, is a unique opportunity for a debate about a sector that takes great importance in the balance of local development of the ultra-peripheral regions.

Madara is particularly interested in the ongoing discussion and considers it imperative to propose the differentiation between craft and industrial fleets that should benefit from different fishing regimes.
It is essential to defend a principle of positive discrimination in which it is necessary to limit access to territorial waters within the exclusive economic zone only to local artisan fleets.
In Madeira, support for the modernization of boats is a priority, as well as a gestion that guarantees the conservation of a large group of species in the long term.
Only in this way will we be able to avoid unsustainable situations for economic, environmental and social balance.
Finally, we will promote the use of permanent and non-dated supports in the other regions of the country.
This report on FEDER has the intention of widening the eligibility of interventions in the housing sector in favour of marginalized communities in our Member States.
Until now, this support was only applied to marginalized communities that resided in the urban areas of the new Member States.
That is, since the vast majority of these communities live in rural areas and in shelters, these communities could not benefit from the support to replace bad quality housing.
It is, in essence, about how to kill a vaccine and give member states and their regions greater possibilities in the mitigation policy of the specific difficulties of these communities.
I also salute the treatment of all Member States, because marginalized communities with the need for support and integration deserve our concern, regardless of the Member State they belong to.

by concluding this important report on the fight against poverty and human dignity, it also achieves its rapid application in the context of the economic relationship plan, responding in a self-reliant way to the crisis that affects us.

Thank you very much, Mr. President. Mr. Commissioner, allow me to start by highlighting the role of the rapporteur, Mr. Van Nistelrooy, for his work in the pursuit of consensus on this matter and also for the availability he has always manifested to incorporate other contributions in his report.
Tomorrow we will vote for changes to the FEDER regulation that are of particular importance to the so-called former Member States and also to Portugal.
These changes will allow the use of FEDER in the housing sector in favour of marginalized communities, since this fund can only be attributed to urban development operations.

The changes proposed, along with other colleagues, and which were approved by the vast majority in the Regional Development Commission, will allow the former Member States, and not only the new ones, as provided by the original proposal, to also benefit from this possibility of financing.
With this, I tried to avoid a precedent that I consider dangerous and that would exclude all the former member states from this and probably from other additional uses of community aid.
which would not make any sense, since the problems of the housing sector, especially among marginalized communities, exist both in the new and the old Member States.
I take this opportunity to reiterate that the antiquity of European accession should not be a criterion for the attribution of structural funds and that this criterion should be eliminated.

The negotiation of the cohesion policy for 2013 should be based on solidarity, aiming at territorial cohesion, and should be oriented to reward instead of punishing the regions that have shown themselves exemplary in the use of community aid.
I would like to highlight the way you have worked with this Parliament during these months of investment.
There is no body in the world with executive and legislative capacity that is subject to the presentation by its President of a program before the Parliament, to the hearing with all the groups

to a vote for an absolute and expressive majority, bringing here all the commissioners to be listened to one by one with their own program, with three to four hours of direct questions, of questions with answers.

someone who accepted to negotiate with the Parliament a framework agreement, in which he accepted, first of all, to justify and to expand the powers of the Parliament in the context of the legislative initiative.

that accepted the principle of total access to information, whether in legislative and political action, or in international negotiations, that accepted to take into account the Parliament's opinion on the commissioners, on the remodeling of the commissioners,
This means, once and for all, and from my point of view, that the Commission has proven, from July until now, that it is willing to have a close connection with the Parliament and that,

to do so, clearly demonstrated, evidently and unequivocally, that the strategic alliance of the Treaty of Lisbon for the community method of which the colleague Sariuszowski spoke is the alliance between the Parliament and the Commission.
and therefore the Commission and the Quadro Agreement deserve the full support of the PPR.
Five years after the Orange Revolution, Ukrainians seem to look at this period as a lost opportunity.

Many reforms were to be fulfilled, many did not pass the test.
