and translates the unpraised and unrecommended intentions into its genesis.
and much has to change about the lack of independence of the judicial power, subject to too much influence not only of political power but also of economic agents.
Without a free and independent justice, there is no rule of law, human rights are not guaranteed, there is no foreign investment, there is no progress.
But the blame for this disenchantment is also very much in this Parliament and, essentially, in many Member States.
I would like for a few seconds to put ourselves in the shoes of a citizen of a European country that, due to vicissitudes of history, is not yet a member of the European Union.
What would we expect from the Union?
solidarity

But many chancelleries, with the exclusive concern of not disturbing Moscow, used and abused the permanent intestinal struggles in Kiev to avoid saying, in an unequivocal way, that Ukraine is an independent and sovereign country.
As such, if this majority will is freely expressed by its people and since it meets the established criteria, Ukraine may aspire to be, in the future, a member of the European Union.

I would like to emphasize that in the Insoares regions, air transport provides the only possibility of access and that the operating conditions are conditioned by the size of its flows, passengers and loads.

If there are areas in Soares where the abundance of these flows is desirable for many air operators, attracting competition and low transport prices, thus improving accessibilities, others exist, such as the Azores, where these flows are still reduced, not being attractive or in the interest of operators.

As a result, air rates are higher, which is an obstacle to the mobility of the population and a condencer in the capture of tourists, which allows this enormous potential for development and diversification of its economic base to flourish and be consolidated.
This picture is particularly penalizing in times of crisis as we have been through.

It is therefore fundamental a temporary support that promotes the increase of flux so that the market can work, also sharing these regions of the potential tourist VAT of the goals of the trans-European networks in the approach of the peripheries of Europe.
Thank you very much Mr. President. I take the floor today with my voice covered by the consternation of those who lived and personally witnessed the tragedy that ravaged Madeira last Saturday.
My words are obviously to associate myself with the feeling of pain and mourning that hit the families of the victims who are now 42 years old and who I pay my homage to and respect for their losses.

The true dimension of this catastrophe is yet to be revealed, since the search and rescue teams, which work uninterruptedly since Saturday in a herculean effort to save, are only now beginning to reach the most isolated populations
and we fear that the number of victims may increase.
The scenario is of a large-scale destruction, with high material damages in access roads and totally destroyed bridges and in essential services such as water and electricity supply.
There are about 600 people evicted who lost their homes and personal belongings.
The economic and social impact of this catastrophe prevents people from returning to a normal life course.
But now we need to look ahead.
I also need to give a message of solidarity, hope and trust to people.
We need to help. And it is in this chapter that the European Union and the Parliament in particular have a word. They are fundamental in the process of mobilization of the Solidarity Fund.
And when we are called to intervene, we have to do it quickly because we cannot ask people to wait, especially when they need us the most.

I appeal to the Commission and its President, Dr. Barroso, especially to the Commissioner of Regional Development, Johanna Sane, and I salute her initiative to visit Madeira in the shortest time frame
I ask him to be also bearer of this message of hope, help and support to the reconstruction. Because now it is time to rebuild what is nature, unfortunately, and once again it took us away.
But I'm sure we will. Because, as the Madeira anthem taught me, the people of Madeira are humble, stoic and brave.
is the people who, among the hard rock, worked the land, the work hero on the Agrest mountain.
Through the wood, it will honor its history and, on the path of work, it will fight and achieve its well-being and glory.
We start today this plenary session with a minute of silence

And it was a minute of silence with two meanings. One of solidarity for the victims of this catastrophe that has affected Madeira and its families. And a sense of tribute to all the workers who have helped these victims tirelessly.
But a minute of silence should make us reflect and should also lead us to a reflection that goes beyond what we are doing here.
What we saw in Madeira is a phenomenon that will tend to repeat itself more and more.
Climate change makes extreme phenomena repeat and we have to have answers for them.
We cannot avoid natural disasters, but we must not be condemned to always have such dramatic effects on people's lives.
That is why we must fight for planning and orderly policies that are oriented towards public good.

But I want to finish, Mr. President, with what is most important and brought us here, which is that the European Commission, the European Parliament and the European institutions must have the capacity to give an urgent response to an urgent situation. And for that, the necessary financial resources are needed and the necessary acceleration is needed.
A tribute of solidarity to the families and friends of the victims of the tragic events of Saturday in Madeira Island.

as a Sourian, as a Portuguese and as a European, I cannot fail to support the Parliament and the Union in their manifestation of active solidarity in favour of the Autonomous Region of Madeira and its populations.
It is in the regions where the presence of the Union needs to make sense and it is precisely in these moments when its solidarity is more necessary that it is also more important that it makes sense.

I also want to support the pain of Madeirens and insistently ask European institutions and in particular the Commission to unlock all available means, all means available to them to carry out this aid.
I would also like to underline that when there is a tragedy of this kind, it is much more difficult to attack its consequences when it occurs in poor countries and in poor regions.

But in the case of wood, we must also take into account that the economic basis of wood is directly affected by the fact that, depending on tourism, it has a double consequence when its natural beauties, its accesses, its quality of life is all destroyed.
So, there is a different situation when we have problems of this severity in poor countries, in poor regions and, in particular, in mountainous and touristy regions, such as Madeira.
Hence, it is absolutely essential that all the adaptations that were planned and requested and that were here remembered, in relation to the Solidarity Fund, do not wait any longer.

that they immediately enter into operation, because due to climate change and these processes, unfortunately, they will be repeated, especially in the poorest regions of Europe, which are those that live in torrential regimes in terms of water and extreme drought during the summer. Thank you very much once again, Mr. President.
We are here to talk about the re-invention of the energy system for the European scale through the investment in low-carbon technologies.
I think it is one of the most important challenges, as it is mentioned in the communication that is made.
and it is one of the challenges we have to face centrally. But there is no clarification here and hence the importance of putting these issues and asking for clarification.
It seems that not only the clarification of the financing is missing, but also the political clarification.
We are talking about energy efficiency, carbon capture, nuclear, biofuels, solar energy and we are also talking about energy efficiency as a cheaper way to reduce emissions.
I am surprised that there are other ways, much cheaper, to reduce carbon emissions that do not even consist of this communication, such as, for example, the reduction of the consumption
energy, micro-generation, distribution and different forms of distribution and different projects that do not have to go through the large structures and access to energy.
I think that we would be contributing to more financial clarification to make the plan cheaper.

And therefore, within this political clarification and within this financial clarification, it is still missing to talk about what I think is an absolutely important point, which is the tonic that is permanently placed in public or private partnerships as if they were the solution to everything.
When asked where the money comes from, they tell us from the Commission that it comes from where it is.
I confess that I am no longer clarified by being told that the money will come from where it is without being told exactly where it is.

So, this bet on public-private partnerships, which is systematically made when we talk about low-carbon technologies, we are sure that, not knowing where the money comes from, and knowing that they are public-private partnerships, we know who will pay.
The ones who will pay are the contributors at the beginning, the consumers who, by chance, are also contributors at the end,
And we know that the ones who pay less are the institutions and private organizations that make the investments, are paid by them, but in the end end up manipulating the profits.
And without this clarification, it seems to me that once again we are systematically moving to future generations the bill for the change of the European energy model.

Thank you Mr. President. The European Union recently celebrated, in the context of the World Trade Organization, an agreement with the countries of Latin America, in which it committed to substantially and progressively reduce the tariffs on the import of bananas from these countries.

I call your attention to the fact that such an agreement has directly negative effects on European banana producers, namely on the banana producers of Madeira in Portugal, but also, and in an even more intense way, on the Canary Islands in Spain.

I remind you that the situation of the producers of these regions is already seriously difficult due to the physical and orographic characteristics of the islands and due to the dimension of their explorations, which leads them to have to face permanent difficulties that penalize their development.

It is therefore urgent to take measures to defend the producers of banana, wood and canary, taking into account the serious and immediate impact that the new Geneva Agreement will have on the European import market and consequently on the production and commercialization of bananas from these ultra-peripheral regions.
President, dear colleagues, Mr. Commissioner, as a partner of the Commission for the Employment of Social Affairs, I would like to start by

national, regional and local authorities, the possibility of resorting to clearer and less bureaucratic rules that will allow more flexibility in the adaptation of the programs to the new challenges. Thank you very much.

and not only of the new buildings, but also in the rehabilitation and recovery of existing buildings, degraded or inadequate.

and consumers will have the guarantee that the so-called fibres will have specific characteristics benefiting from the fact that new fibres will arrive earlier in the market.

that the application of this regulation could have increased its competitiveness.

some principles and practices to safeguard.

Madam President and Mr. Commissioner, social housing is a general interest economic service with an important role in the market, creating positive externalities for the benefit of the whole society.
According to Protocol 26, annexed to the Lisbon Treaty, it is up to the national, regional and local authorities to carry out and organize this type of service.
Hence, it is incomprehensible this restriction of the target audience to families with lower income than 33,000 euros.
It is a poverty measurement that is made in absolute and purely financial terms, that does not contemplate the diversity of the 27 Member States, summarizing a simple argumentation of solvency.

Social housing is a response to cultural and social issues, to the proximity of the workplace, to the important redefinition of the role of women in the market, to the mobility of workers in the European space.
The struggle that the European Union is fighting to get out of the current crisis is due to economic growth, which is dragging an increase in immigration and ethnic minorities
economic and cultural and for the need for its integration, even with the risks of ghettoization that are associated with it and that we must fight with fair balance.
Is the Commission not entering the field of competence of the Member States?

I speak exactly with the islanders about their ultra-peripheral regions in a practical demonstration of the will to build a union that is strengthened by cohesion,
in the spirit of active solidarity, respecting the specificities and differences of its parts as the only viable way to build our European Common Project.

healthy agricultural diversification in a region where the oil field occupies, as we know, a unique dimension on a national scale, irreplaceable, that we must sustain and consolidate.

With the entry into operation of the Lisbon Treaty, and despite at the time dominating opinion by other political groups, as well as the Council and the Commission, so that the proposal continues in simplified process, because they understood that

proposal did not need alterations and that it should quickly come into force, despite the fact that I and the Socialist and Democratic group understand that the Parliament should be pronounced already within the scope of the Lisbon Treaty, assuming its role as legislator.

We did it in a good time because, from then on, new possibilities were opened, first with the contribution of the Regional Development Commission and the presence of our colleague Nuno Teixeira, to whom I take the opportunity to

I would like to thank the Cooperation always provided in this process and then with my report introducing the new possibilities for sugar in the Azores, as well as with the contribution and support of colleagues of the Commission of Agriculture.

I would like to say, finally, in this first intervention, that in the face of the changes proposed by the Regi Commission and voted in the Agri Commission and supported by me, we cannot accept the commitment obtained in the Triunfo.

It was essential to obtain a commitment at first reading, thus saving the improvements already achieved and the need to enter into force so as not to compromise its retroactivity since January of this year.
However, the Commission is already preparing a document for review of the POSEI, we will return soon to have the opportunity to debate it.

Thank you very much Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, dear colleagues. We are facing an acceleration of a global change that has devastating consequences for our economic, political and social systems and for all our citizens.
We are witnessing today a fragilization of the capacity of the response of the States.
The European Union is determined to identify common and allied causes and act clearly and united in the world scene.
Extraordinary situations require a lucidity of joint action.

If we do not take the measures of rigor and collective responsibility that are imposed, Europe will be voted to marginalization and impoverishment. And only a strong Europe, respecting its common rules, will be able to give the right answer to the new times.
The fragile and indebted states have no capacity to protect their citizens.

Because we need to be able to regain the trust of citizens, to win the battles of stability, of budgetary rigor, of job creation, of stability of the monetary union, of globalization and of strategic choices.
This is because we are committed to our future.
and the future is gained by betting on social cohesion, ensuring peace, building a new model based on values of freedom, social justice and responsibility.
Thus, the 2020 Strategy and the integrated EU-2020 guidelines constitute essential instruments for a new cycle of growth and employment in Europe.
For a correct implementation and realization, it is necessary that quantifiable and clear objectives are defined in employment, education and reducing poverty.

It is also decisive for the success of the strategy that everything is done to facilitate the transposition by the Member States of their national objectives and to ensure a correct execution of this strategy. Thank you very much.
When the Economic and Monetary Union completed 10 years, the Commission considered the Euro the most successful project of the Union.
Today we would have difficulty in affirming it without limitations, because the crisis showed the evidence that the economic and monetary union is an unfinished project.
Minimum safety measures were taken in an emergency climate, but let's not be fooled. The conditions of pressure, the direct interests of the main
member countries, the painful nature of the decisions, their slowness, have weakened the image of the Euro and the European Union before citizens and the world.
We must face the facts.
The European Union and the Euro are a process of integration, not merely cooperation between countries.
It is an unfinished process that at this moment either reinforces itself or there are serious risks of its disappearance.
There are three issues that must be addressed. First, it is important to consolidate the instruments that were launched in this climate of emergency. It is necessary to create a monetary fund

Europe, we need to move forward with Eurobonds, we need to move forward with the architecture of European supervision and regulation and we need to move forward with a European dimension in the management of banking crises.
Second dimension, it is important to understand that there is no strong currency if the economy is weak. The growth of 1% expected for the European Union is unsustainable in terms
both in terms of its demographic composition and in terms of combating unemployment. Strategy 2020 is nothing more than a set of good ideas if there are no means of realization.

Third dimension, Mr. Commissioner Ollirane, fiscal consolidation is important, but it cannot coexist with increasing divergences between the member states that make up the Union. The convergence policy must be urgently revisited. Thank you very much, Mr. President.
Thank you very much, Mr. President. Several colleagues here from the PPR have already made a very complete picture of the situation.
I think that now it will be necessary to make a reference to the role of the national states.
In fact, the national governments also have a role here in the sense of imposing on their states the demands
and the conditions for the single currency to be strengthened and this project of monetary and economic integration to be taken forward.
And here I would like to say that our party, the party linked to the PPE, which is the PSD, in Portugal, is supporting the government in austerity measures, because we consider

that the mistakes that the Socialist Government has committed over the past 15 years, and that today, unfortunately, are in the sight of all, that these mistakes need to be fixed and will have the support of the PSD to be fixed.

But if we are supporting austerity measures, we also criticize the Portuguese government. And it is a good example for other analogous cases because it is not reducing the expenditure. And what is fundamental is not only

to increase taxes to reduce the deficit, but it is to reduce the expense. It is to demand from the government that it has the courage to take measures that reduce the expense, that alleviate the deficit, that alleviate the public debt.
This applies to Portugal and to other States that are in a difficult situation. And we, as European Parliamentarians, have the responsibility to make our countries
of the necessary measures to strengthen the Euro and to make this space of integration, this dream, which is a dream of the PPE and which is a dream of all of us, possible.
That is why we criticize those governments that do not have the courage to take the necessary measures in their states.

Dear colleagues, I would like to start by saying that the report on the evaluation of the results of the 2016-2010 Roteiro for the Equality between Men and Women, which aims to influence the strategies on this matter for the future, could, in our opinion, have been more assertive and less controversial.

In fact, the way of addressing several ethically sensitive issues, namely the issue of women's sexual and reproductive health, should have been different if the objective was really to obtain the greatest possible consensus.

This said, I would like to emphasize that in times of economic growth, the concern for women's rights, namely the disparity between the situation of men and women in work, society and family, is great. But these problems are deeply aggravated by the economic and social crisis we are living in.
Hence the need for a strategic commitment reinforced by the Member States at the level of local and regional entities and community institutions in what concerns the protection

I would like to say that, in line with what President Dou and my colleague Werner Langan said, it is essential that there is an Economic Government of the Union, but that this Economic Government is focused on the Commission.
This is the first point I would like to highlight. And, having said that, we should not only, as we did today and tomorrow, focus our debate on immediate issues,
but also those that are in the 2020 strategy. And I would highlight in particular the issue of education and training for the younger people, the issue of innovation, research and development.

because these are the niches that will allow Europe to be competitive in the global space. And today I must say that, unfortunately, the European educational model failed. And it failed because when compared to the model of emerging countries,

as India, China and Brazil, is today a less demanding and less rigorous model. Therefore, I also ask that in the audacity of this idea of innovation, development, research and education, there is rigor and demand in the context of European educational systems.
Only with this rigor and demand, we will prepare our young people to compete in the global market.

We cannot think only about the crisis of this year or the next two or three years. We must think about the strategy for Europe in the next 10 to 20 years. And it depends on a rigorous and demanding educational system.
Mr. Commissioner, never before, as it is today, has the European project, built with such great effort in the last 50 years, been so threatened.

The frustration of European citizens is enormous. The financial system that should serve them destroyed their savings, their pensions, their investment projects, their jobs, and in short, their future.

Regarding the necessary robustness of the entire market of financial services, banks, insurance, real estate values, the path to follow is clear and lies in the architecture that we discuss here today.
We need a European supervision architecture, strong, that covers all products and actors, that is endowed with methodologies and instruments
effective interventions and that is able to respond to the reality of a market that, especially in the European context, does not recognize national borders.

The risk cannot or should not be eliminated from the financial market, but we need regulation that makes this risk more transparent and that avoids the accumulation of bubbles whose explosion affects the entire system and drags the real economy.

But if, despite these defenses, new crises occur in the future, it is crucial to expose mechanisms that limit contagion, especially in what concerns the banking system, because this is vital for the functioning of the economy and the depository of citizens' savings.

Here, exactly in the powers and competences of the banking authority, resides the capacity to execute a new strategy on the management of cross-border crises in the banking sector, the subject of which my report refers.
It is not in our hands to prevent the bankruptcy of banks, but to ensure that their reorganization or eventual liquidation are made
in an orderly manner, limiting the collateral effects on the rest of the system and, above all, preventing the contributor from paying the costs of the crises they generate.

For this, a set of new devices is necessary. Rules, definitions, methodologies, instruments and terminology must be adopted, common to all stakeholders in restructuring, reorganization or liquidation operations.
It is necessary to harmonize the relevant national legal frameworks for crisis management, namely the bankruptcy and liquidation laws.
it is necessary to make an attribution of powers extended of intervention to supervisors.
it is necessary to design clear criteria, not only quantitative but also qualitative, that allow to initiate interventions in an institution in difficulties.
contingency plans must be prepared.
This whole process for 27 Member States requires time.
However, about 50 banks out of the 12,000 operating in Europe represent 70% of the assets.
This means a huge risk concentration, but also an opportunity to intervene on them.

There are conditions to propose a special and urgent process of bank meeting, which being transborder, due to its dimension, relations with other banks have a possible systemic impact on the financial system.
For these banks it is possible to anticipate a special supervision by the new European Banking Authority, although operating in the National Supervisory College,
It is possible and urgent that they, depending on the risk they generate, start to make contributions to a fund that finances the possible interventions
that are necessary and it is important that the banking authority creates a specialized unit that coordinates the interventions in case of difficulty in these banks.
In its set, the proposed elements ensure that the interventions in transnational banks of a systemic nature are consistent and coherent
and above all, that a principle so expensive in Europe be fulfilled, that the costs of pollution caused by these banks are supported by the polluter himself.
This proposal fits perfectly in what we are discussing, especially in the competences of the banking authority. I would even say that it is the most evident test of its effectiveness.
In the case of the vote in the Economic and Monetary Committee, there was a very large majority of support for this proposal, 87% of the votes.
We also have a solid vote from this institution, in the sense that, by supporting this visionary proposal, which is realistic but pragmatic,
Let's make an action that is urgent and necessary to re-launch the hope of the Europeans in Europe, in their financial system and in particular in the banking system. Thank you very much.
Thank you.

Deflux, as we know, is one of the main environmental and social problems of the planet and every year we lose 13 million hectares of forest, contributing thus to 20% of the global carbon emissions and constituting a huge threat to biodiversity.

This illegal practice puts at risk the sustainable exploitation of wood and the companies that make it.

To close, Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, the objective of territorial cohesion, now enshrined in the Lisbon Treaty, materializes the value of European solidarity and the commitment of the Member States and the Union to reduce the existing disparities between the various regions.
However, it is not enough to express in the text of the Treaties the objectives to be achieved.
There are regions of the Union that have permanent constraints that strongly condition their economic and social development.

Therefore, it is necessary to implement specific programs that allow to effectively and realistically overcome the delay of these regions by promoting an adaptation of your development model to your potential and resources and contribute to achieve the objectives of the EU 2020 strategy.
This incentive to these regions should result not only from the means of regional policy, through its structural adjustment instruments such as the Coesão Fund and the four structural funds,
also of a different use of the various sectoral policies that have in each region a relevant territorial impact and can therefore have a dynamic effect on their economies.
For the determination of European assistance to these regions, it is certain that we must keep the GDP as the main indicator of eligibility.

However, taking into account its natural disadvantages, it is relevant to resort to other measurable criteria capable of providing a more real picture of its level of development, such as unemployment rate, population density or education level.
Only then will it be possible to have a more complete picture of the complex reality of the most disadvantaged regions.

I would like to highlight the case of the ultra-peripheral regions, which the statute was recognized by the new treaty and which are a group of regions of the European Union that have specific characteristics and also deserve special treatment.
The regions of the ultra-periphery, united because of their particular characteristics, also differ in their levels of development.

Also in relation to these, complementary indicators of GDP should be used, capable of providing a more complete description of their specific reality and thus contribute to a more exact determination of their level of development. Thank you very much.

Thank you, Mr. President. The price of food has reached its historic maximum, which is the seventh consecutive increase.
There are several factors that can explain this increase, the first being a short-term factor,
This has to do with the coincidence of bad weather conditions in some countries, such as Russia and Argentina,
But there are two structural factors, and that is why I bring these two factors here.
The first has to do with the fact that some food producers and consumers who were exporters, now become importers, as is the case in China.
And the second has to do with the fact that the weight of some big multinationals, being able to make the prices fall in their favor.
And the example of cereals is this very clear level. It is dominated by six major multinationals.
This situation puts farmers in a huge uncertainty about the prices of food.
Europe should, therefore, do what it has not done for some time, that is, protect its producers and consumers.
In a world where everyone uses protective methods and where multinationals manipulate prices, we cannot continue to be naive. Thank you.

Thank you very much, Mrs. President. Dear colleagues, Mr. Commissioner Stefan Fuller, The historical moment we live in claims a firm and determined action.
Like many of you, it is with a mixture of hope, concern and expectation that we watch the events that unfold in the Mediterranean basin.

However, I am satisfied with the proactive position that the Parliament is preparing to adopt in what concerns the revision of the European policy of the Southern neighborhood, which I hope will lead to a greater presence of the Union in this area, not only as a payer, but also as a committed partner.
First, by affirming the absolute need to defend our founding values in relations with neighboring countries.
We cannot go beyond the defense of democracy, nor the defense of human rights, and much less the defense of social justice.

We will no longer be able to privilege the stability of the short term, at the expense of the higher interests of citizens and their intransigent defence, their individual and collective freedom, with particular attention to women's rights.
In the future, the Union has to privilege an approach from the base to the top in its policy of proximity.
It is essential that this happens.
Only the greatest involvement of local communities and civil society will guarantee maximum efficiency in its implementation.

But I cannot let the frustration spread. I regret that this Parliament and the Commission do not want to take this opportunity to differentiate, at times, the East-Berlin policy with the countries that may potentially be, in the future, our partners in the Union, from the South-Berlin policy.
I challenge the Commission to demonstrate, in its 20th of April review process, the ambition that the moment now claims, a policy of close proximity
tailor-made to the measure of each State, with clear benchmarks and a careful assessment that allows to take to a future Mediterranean economic space with the new democracies of the South.

Finally, we trust that the good environment and cooperation that have characterized the works on this subject will lead to a permanent involvement of the European Parliament in the planning and evaluation of this policy.

I also want to join my voice to all those who here have expressed concerns about the low yields of fishermen, aggravated by historical prices, hit by fuels, particularly in recent months.
As it was well said here, the fuel costs have a very high impact on the survival of our small and medium-sized arms, aggravating in particular the already fragile fishing yields.
This prestigious rise in prices is also bringing us deep negative effects. Reduction of sea departures, miseries from fishermen aggravated by low prices paid in the first sale,
increases in the imports of land from aquaculture and fishing products to the European market and a consequent abandonment of activity due to financial difficulties, such as the loss of jobs.
In this context, to avoid the continuity of the crisis, it is necessary to act and act with clarity and depth in the fishing problems.

Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, I would like to start by saying that, naturally, I believe that the agreement that was found for Portugal is a balanced agreement.

and I think that is very positive.

I do not take the attitude of others who consider that countries like Greece, Ireland and Portugal did everything right. They did not make mistakes, they did not exaggerate, they did everything right and it was only the international crisis that caused problems.

No, our governments have made mistakes and had wrong policies. But that doesn't mean that there is no opportunity in the context of the Union to have the possibility to go back to the right path and the correct path.

And that's why it's important to remember here that, in fact, we need to tell public opinions that are against the support of countries in difficulties that they are not giving money to those countries, they are just lending money to those countries.
but they are lending them at very high interest rates and therefore they are doing a business that is positive for their budgets and for their populations.

and more responsibility than the one that existed in the last council, in which it sought to solve a problem for three months only because of electoral calendars.

I hope that this decision of responsibility will essentially be understood. That economic and financial issues are crucial and decisive for Europe. But that economic and financial issues are instrumental for what is the main purpose of Europe, which is the purpose of maintaining peace.
If an approach is made to the problems that leads only to the states starting to distrust each other, to install distrust between the different states,

is an irresponsible speech, which often even appeals to some characteristics of nationalities that are extremely negative.

Thank you very much, Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner. My first words are to highlight the work developed by the rapporteur, my colleague, Jorge Sotravakakis, who did an extraordinary job in identifying the future synergies for a reinforced efficiency among the various structural funds.

Its report also includes, in this joint debate on the Coesão policy, a debate that assumes greater importance not only for the substance of the subject, but also and above all for the opportunity in terms of the timing of its discussion.
Indeed, we are now on the way to know the Commission's proposal not only regarding the new financial prospects, but also regarding the future cohesion policy for 2013.
The policy of cohesion is a fundamental policy for the European Union.

It is a horizontal policy that, through its excellent instruments and structural funds, finances projects and programs in the Member States, seeking to reduce disparity between the levels of development of the various regions.
The experience has shown us the difficulties in terms of efficiency and results resulting from the fragmentation and complexity of this policy.

and that a unique strategic framework for the various funds, with an integrated approach and focused on the results, is the starting point for more and better synergies between the various instruments and for the reinforcement of its effectiveness.
It is also essential for better coordination between the various sectoral policies and for better efficiency in the application of resources.
We must take advantage of the crisis to look for new alternatives.

And it is certain that all these reports that are here today in discussion will pose enormous challenges. And we know that to respond to these challenges we also need a good budget. But we have to make a clear distinction between what are the budgetary aspects and the political objectives.
The political objectives are well known and, in fact, only by affirming these political objectives can we offer a future to the regions.
And if that's the case, we must then put the budget at the service of the future of the regions and citizens, and not the citizens and regions at the service of the budget. Thank you very much.
Thank you Mr. President. The cohesion policy is the key policy for the future of the European project.
The construction of a common space with an internal market, a currency, requires a certain level of convergence of its member states and its regions to work.
The current differences in competitiveness and development asymmetries inevitably led to the fragilisation of the European space and the crisis affecting the Eurozone.
That is why this vital need for convergence absolutely needs a powerful cohesion budget and that cannot be weakened to finance other policies.
The European Union, to do more, must have more. And this is achieved by growing its budget and not by reducing, even if skillfully, the budget of the Coesão.

I therefore ask the Commissioner if the creation of the Fund for Infrastructure and New Innovation Policies, which will be articulated with the Coesão and Regional Development, which I support, without an increase in the community budget, will not be able to transform into the Trojan horse introduced in the Coesão budget.

Modernization and renewal of the energy infrastructure are essential factors for the goals of sustainable and intelligent growth that we seek with the 2020 Strategy and for the energy security that we need.
It is essential to involve all regions in this challenge.

For this reason, the incentives provided in the regulatory systems must be improved, namely those that apply to projects of greater risk and more innovative projects, such as those that are being developed in the islands of the Azores in renewable energies.

Regions must be associated with the phases of conception and implementation of projects, in defining priorities, in their elaboration and execution, because this guarantees better results and, therefore, a better defense of the European interest.

The current economic moment even more emphasizes the need to adopt an innovative approach integrated with energy issues, so that all aspects, economic, environmental and social, are taken into account.
It is essential not to lose sight of its effects in the medium and long term, seeking to ensure all European citizens a safe, sustainable and acceptable energy.

The report we are debating is of particular importance, taking into account the influence that social services of general interest have on the daily lives of European citizens, as well as on social cohesion, on the creation of employment and on economic growth.

The national authorities are the ones who have the skills to define, organize and finance the social services of general interest.
Thus, it is unnecessary to create harmonizing legislation at the European level, given that the realities of these social services of general interest in the 27 Member States are very diverse.

Just look at the health, social security, employment and social housing services, which are examples that proximity and knowledge of contexts are the cornerstone for the adequate and fairer performance of these services. Thank you very much.

Mr. President, as a reporter of the Regi's appearance on the future of the Social and International Services, I would like to congratulate my colleague Rosa by underlining the fact that we are facing an essential pillar of the social economy model of the market that we defend for Europe and in which the SIC plays a fundamental role in its cohesion.

Social cohesion at the European Union level advises not to discourage the existence of minimum protection levels in all Member States, without prejudice, due to the respect of the competences of its national, regional and local authorities.

European regions have a very important role in providing these services to the populations and their opinion must be taken into account given the nature of their constraints to guarantee the populations their performance.

In a time of crisis, as we are now going through, the social services in general constitute a social protection network for the most disadvantaged or for those whose performance does not allow them access to private services.

It is therefore important to ensure that Member States that decentralize powers make them follow the respective financial means so that regional and local authorities can ensure their good performance to the populations.

Thank you Mr. President. I would like to start by congratulating the rapporteur and everyone who contributed to achieve this work.
There is no doubt that this report will constitute a reference in what concerns the recommendations and the solid and coordinated responses to the crisis challenges.
If there is a conclusion that can be drawn, it is that the crisis we are living in will only be overcome with the deepening of European integration.

In a time of serious financial, economic and social difficulties and painful austerity measures in some member states, like in my country, Portugal, it is an attempt to take refuge in a protectionist and nationalist attitude.
But that's a mistake.

The European response to the crisis is through a true European economic government that pursues sustainable growth, promotes the creation of employment and develops the social market economy, giving long-term responses with defined objectives with which the Member States identify themselves.
The strategy to get out of the crisis needs to be financed with a sufficiently ambitious community budget.

To avoid a new crisis of sovereign debt and the euro, it is necessary a more strict coordination in the matter of budgetary policies, as well as the creation of a system of issuing of public debt and euro debt.
I end by underlining that in this difficult period it is also necessary to maintain the levels of social protection, especially for the most vulnerable citizens. Thank you very much.
Thank you, Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, President in exercise. It is usual to say that crises help to strengthen Europe.
Historically it was like that, but today I'm not so sure that this is still true.

The slow, improvised, reactive way in which the Union is reacting to the Greek crisis aggravates the situation every day and casts the contagion and lack of trust in the Union and its currency in a frightening way.
This, despite the problems of the Eurozone, resulted in obvious failures in the construction of the single currency, which today focuses on its weakest links.

For the current crisis to result in the strengthening of the Union, it is necessary a strategic vision, as there was in the past, and unfortunately neither the Commission nor the Council have been able to print to the European Programme and Project.
This Parliamentary report gives us this vision, however. More Europe and no less is the solution.
The Parliament reminds that the market and the single currency generate unbearable divergences between economies and that they must be opposed by specific policies.

It recognizes that the functioning of the euro requires a European budget reinforced by its own resources, requires a European debt-solidary emission agency capable of protecting the states from market speculation,

and provide them with credit at reasonable prices and deadlines. It also recognizes that the diplomas and the transferability of workers between countries require mutual recognition of social rights and pensions.
The Parliament has united to send clear messages. We hope that the Commission and the Council will hear them.

Mr. President, Mrs. Commissioner, dear colleague rapporteur, first of all I would like to congratulate and congratulate the colleague rapporteur for considering that this report is extremely useful and allows us to take new steps in the area of mediation.

Directive 2852 CE of the European Parliament and the Council of May 21, 2008, relating to the mediation in civil and commercial matters.
We all know the advantages of mediation.
On the one hand, it is a judicial measure to resolve conflicts, it contributes to the decongestion of the courts, to the rationalization of the justice system, providing, at the same time,
simultaneously providing the parties with the possibility of obtaining a more friendly, faster, less expensive and less expensive solution to the litigation in which they were being held.

It is therefore crucial to reaffirm the objective of the first article of the Directive when it appeals to the adoption of measures of incentive to the resource, to alternative resolution means of litigation and, in particular, to mediation.
Promoting access and use of judicial means to resolve conflicts contributes to improving, simplifying and making our justice more accessible.

This is why it is a very important challenge for the European Union and for the establishment of a space of freedom, security and justice, I would say, for the idea of rule of law within the European Union.
And that is why, in this context of crisis, I consider it very important that, as stated in the report, public opinion can be sensitized,
and appeal to the Commission and to the Commissioner to present a legislative proposal on the alternative resolution of the litigation.

Thank you very much, Mr. President, Commissioner-Chief Kovic, Council representatives, Polish Presidency. First of all, I would like to clarify that I will intervene here in a dual quality. On the one hand, substituting the author of the opinion of the Commission on

my colleague Messer Schmidt, from Denmark, who is absent due to the election process in Denmark at the moment. Therefore, I am representing him as a member of AFCO, but also as a member of the jury, as a shadow reporter in the jury of this report.
The first thing I would like to say is that, in the economic and financial crisis, the issue of smart regulation is a central issue.

There is no doubt that in the so-called structural reforms that can make the economic and financial start of the European space, also the improvement at the level of legislation and regulation is absolutely essential.

It is evident that a Europe that is intended, on a dynamic and competitive side, must have simple and accessible regulations to companies and, obviously, to citizens. And therefore, it must be oriented to its needs.
The truth is that, in this sense, it is essential today that, first of all, the program of reduction of administrative orders is reached, that all efforts are made in the sense of
to promote consultations to market agents, to representative associations of citizens and companies, and to evaluate the impact of the legislation itself, this is also extremely important, so that

the decision-making process can essentially have as a basis the opinion of those who are destinators of legislation and that can be done without administrative charges and with less economic and financial costs.

It is important to say that, for the Commission of Constitutional Affairs in particular, the idea of the principle of proportionality and subsidiarity is relevant. This idea that European intervention should be an adequate intervention and not an intervention that promotes the complexification of the system

and the regulation system. And so, we pay special attention, in our opinion, to the reinforced role that the national parliaments have in this dynamic, precisely because of the principle of proportionality and the principle of subsidiarity.

That is why it is essential that, also at the level of the Smart Regulation and at the level of the improvement of the legislation, we now involve the national parliaments, so that, on the European level and on the national level, both the legislation and the regulation

be more agile, more intelligent, more efficient. And so this is a good time to put into practice what we announce every day, which is a more competitive Europe and a more agile Europe through a more intelligent argumentation.
Mr. President, the number of people without shelter, as well as the number of people living below the poverty line, has not stopped increasing in recent years in several Member States.
The economic, financial and social crisis and the increase in unemployment have aggravated this problem as everyone has already diagnosed.
We all agree that this phenomenon is the denial of important values of the European Union, respect for human dignity and respect for fundamental rights.
In my country, for example, which is subject to a strong measure of austerity, the concept of homeless according to the national plan involves people who will ask for help to take a meal.
and the number of people seeking help to eat increased by more than 20% since 2008.
There is a greater increase in families and people in need who saw their situation of life changed by unemployment and also by banking indebtedness.
This is just one example that demonstrates the gravity of this situation.
Last year, the European Parliament approved a written statement on a strategy of the European Union for the homeless.

With this declaration, this Parliament alerted to the need of the European Union to adopt a strategy supported by national and regional strategies, with the long-term goal of ending the situations of people who sleep on the street and the state without long-term shelter.

National strategies should focus on preventive measures, but also on concrete actions to improve the quality of services provided to the homeless and the availability of accommodation at affordable prices.
It is also evident that this European strategy must be compatible with the policy of social housing of Member States.
We took note of the Commissioner's words and recorded the situation that made us.
I end by exhorting the European Commission to give a strong impulse to coordinate the action of Member States and regional authorities in the sense of combating this social injustice. Thank you.
We are debating the peace process in the Middle East. But is there any ongoing process that has escaped me?
Unfortunately, no.

The European Union is repeatedly pronounced, like most of the international community, by the existence of two peoples and two states, sharing the space between the Jordan River and the Mediterranean, which have the right to aspire to live in peace and security.
but without dialogue between the parties, in which, being in a sea of hatred and misunderstandings that has been going on for 63 years, only extremisms and frustrations are fed.

It is essential that Europe and the Arab League get involved much more in the search for a negotiated solution for the borders, based on the existing ones in 1967, with the exchanges that allow the majority of Jewish colonies to stay in Israel.

May the question of Jerusalem, the Holy City, future capital of the two States, be clarified and mutually accepted as a symbol of peaceful coexistence between two peoples who have the obligation to realize the prophecy of Isaiah that this is the land of milk and honey.

that all the countries of the world participate in the resolution of the Palestinian refugee issue and that the international community, and in particular the Arab nation, participate in the necessary financial compensation.

It is still absolutely essential that a military force under the aegis of the UN and the participation, among others, of American and Islamic forces, be placed on the ground as a guarantee of peacekeeping.
So be it courage and political will.

Thank you, Mr. President. Mr. Commissioner, tourism needs a clear and coordinated European approach, with an attentive look at the potential and challenges that the different tourist modes have to offer us.
The diversity of tourism that the European Union presents is so rich that it allows an exponential growth of this sector and of the European Union's own competitiveness.

A bet in this key sector, which represents 10% of GDP and about 12% of employment in the European Union, will allow us to create not only European added value, but also to face the economic crisis we are facing.
It comes from an ultra-peripheral region, Madeira, where tourism is the main economic activity.

and therefore the creation of a specific section for the sector in the financial framework of 2014-2020 is essential for a cohesive and sustainable growth of tourism, which is essentially composed of small and medium-sized companies.

The realization of a truly sustainable and diversified European tourism policy requires a concrete strategic plan, with a well-defined calendar, actions and financing capable of reinforcing the visibility and quality of the tourism sector in the European Union.

Refugees, there are about 4.8 million and have the right to their dignity, to a future linked to a land of preference to yours.

Thank you, Mr. President. Madam Commissioner, since we have been talking about the shameful situation that is experienced in refugee camps in Tunisia, we all share, and I share a lot of what my colleagues who have just spoken said,

and there were children who were enrolled in public schools, which has implications at the level of infrastructure, has implications at the level of what is the reception in these countries.

And in Europe,
What can you do?
How does Europe live so well with this double criteria?
We are so fast to repatriate and so slow to help, Madam Commissioner.
