Mr. President, I would like to naturally congratulate you for this supplement of hope that you have given to all the European deputies and in particular to the citizens of the European Union that we represent here.

And, having said that, I would like to say that we expect from the Commission a very, very decisive action, together with the Council, so that this crisis of sovereign debt can be resolved in the short term.
We know it's a marathon, but we need immediate results.

And therefore, without a doubt, if we all start thinking about a change in the treaties that would give political translation to the whole project that we brought here today, without a doubt, something must be done already.

this set of measures and, hopefully, an agreement between the States, what I call a kind of parasocial agreement that goes beyond the treaties and that can, from this moment, put these ideas into action.
Congratulations for your courage and determination.
I believe we are on the right track and we will leave today with another determination.
The crisis that the European Union is going through has had serious consequences in all member states and thousands of workers are affected by the waste caused by globalization and the crisis.
We cannot fail to affirm our solidarity with these workers who have lost their jobs and to affirm that Europe must help Member States to maintain a wage and fight unemployment.
A rapid reintegration of workers in the labour market is a priority.

An example of the usefulness of this fund is my country, Portugal, which has been referred to it four times, although we were aware that access to this fund could be improved, especially in the countries most affected by the crisis.

Thanks to the existence of this Fund for Globalization, it has been possible to help thousands of workers through professional training measures, and already helps to create companies and incentives for recruitment.

This proposal is positive because it will allow Member States to ask for the intervention of this fund to support the workers who are fired as a direct consequence of the economic and financial crisis

We support the delay of the deadline and we understand that the member states most affected by the crisis should have greater access and easier access to this fund that supports globalization and the crisis.
Thank you, President. I congratulate the Polish Presidency and also the Deputy Commissioner Ali Ren, just to say that I consider that
And today, in the development of what was done in the Union State discourse, a very big step has been taken to solve the problems of the crisis in the European Union.
because the Commission has taken on its commitment to use its initiative power and to use it together with the Council to resolve this crisis.
I believe this is an extremely important step and it is the only way we have at this moment to resolve the crisis in the Eurozone.
There is no possibility of solving this issue in the short term only with an intergovernmental approach. And so it is necessary that the States, the Governments of the States,
the Commission, the instruments and the mandate to lead this process of resolution, to put into practice, execute and develop this roadmap that was presented here.
But I would not want to say that this is not incompatible with the fact that we are developing at the same time our capacity to alter the treaties.

I am also convinced that in the medium term we need to change the treaties, but we will have to do it in the sense of reinforcing, in the sense of giving more strength and greater position to the Commission.

is by strengthening the community metric, now in the short term, and then with a change of treaties in the long term, that we will achieve more integration and a solution for the 17 countries in the Eurozone and for the 27 countries in the European Union.

Thank you, Mr. President. Dr. Durão Barroso came here today to announce as one of the measures that banks that do not have capital requirements must present plans to obtain them and if they cannot present them, they must then suspend their dividends and bonuses.
I could not fail to agree with this presentation that was made by the President.
This week we saw what happened with the bank Zexia and a few months ago an administrator of this bank received a prize of 600,000 euros for his wonderful administration as we know.
But to be serious, Mr. President, the Commission has to go to the Governments and present the complete package. And the complete package is what is essential.
The essential is that the money of the contributors has as a counterpart a policy of credit for growth.
The essential is that banks start to pay taxes on their profits, which does not happen in many countries, namely in my country, Portugal.
In two years, or rather in three years, it is the second time that they ask us to save the banks with the money of the unemployed.
the banks that also save the economy, helping to create jobs. Thank you very much.
Mr. Deputy Representative, there are times when I think that we need to do some work and make some adjustments, and this seems to be one of those times.
And it seems to me that we are always in the cadence of events and the response from event to event and we lose a bit of what is the perspective of the whole.

It is true that each case is a case and each country we are talking about is a specific case, but forgive me, High Representative, it seems to me that it is difficult to scrutinize the criteria that the European Union has used to act according to each of the cases.
I fear that we are often hostages of the interests of some of the countries of the European Union, and not of all.
And that is why we use so many times in this House the expression of two weights and two measures and we continue to use it.

Sometimes it is sanctions yes, sometimes it is sanctions no. Sometimes the interference goes to the limit of the bomb, as was the case in Libya. Other times it is total silence, as was the case of the Baran invasion by the forces of

Saudi Arabia. And Mrs. Baroness, let me tell you, I have studied all the dossiers carefully, I have not seen a single declaration of the European institutions condemning the invasion of Bahrain by the Saudi Arabian military forces.

Condemnations to death, endless violence, doctors and nurses who are sentenced to 30 years in prison by a military court because they were supposedly against the regime and not helping the victims they needed.
In relation to the dictatorship monarchy of Bahrain, in relation to the dictatorship regime of Yemen, the regime of Saleh, we have had much more silence than actions.

I am not in favour of the management, I never was, but I fear that we will put ourselves in a uncomfortable position, the position seen from the outside, Mrs. Baronessa, which is, instead of helping the development, the aspirations

democratic and revolutionary movements of the people in the Arab countries, instead of helping the Arab first, what we do is to prevent it from extending, either by excess or by defect, and I don't think we should keep that sin.
I hope that the awarding of the Nobel Prize to an activist like Yamita can be a sign that we are on the side of the people who are in revolution. Thank you very much.
Thank you, Mr. President. Mr. Commissioner, this is a good report from my colleague Casa.
First of all, we must ask why we are reviewing the European Union's IVA?
First, there is the need to make it compatible with the single market
the more regimes and varieties of IVA, the less fluid the market will be.
A reform of the IVA favors e-commerce, focuses on the value and price base of goods and services and not on tax differences.
It fights fraud and guarantees the trust needed, especially in transborder transactions. It improves the economy of SMEs and reduces administrative orders.
What other measures are already in progress in the single market that can be associated with IVA?
First, a simple, clear and transparent digital support mechanism, the SETE measure of the single market.
5. The need to review the legislation on the normalization and implementation of the Directive
the new measure that aims to remove tax obstacles and to explicitly review the IVA system and the equalization of IVA in online and face-to-face trade, which we all feel when we order books.
The pressures for the reform of the IVA have two fundamental reasons.
First of all, the economic crisis
More revenue is needed, including, probably, in some countries, the reduction of labour contributions to promote economic development, passing this commission to the IEA.
Secondly, the second major source of pressure is population aging, demographic aging and the tendency to pass indirect taxes on direct taxes, due to the reduction of the population base of incidence.
It is necessary to rethink the balance between this direct and indirect supervisory system.
Finally, we must, in these reforms, reconcile subsidiarity with harmonization.
It is necessary to restrict the variation interval in the normal IVA rate so that we can all understand each other better.
It is necessary greater transparency in the definition of the reduced VAT rate and its application field, a clear and comprehensive list of reduced rates.
It is necessary to study exemptions for SMEs, knowing that each exemption brings with it a cortege of small or large frauds.
Finally, I would like to greet the recent proposal of the Commission to create a European IVA.
Thank you, Mrs President. I would like to thank my colleague Rula for the excellent report he prepared.
The advantages of public procurement are certainly known, but the obstacles are also evident. Interest conflicts between European legislation and the objectives of Member States harm competitiveness.
The dichotomy of price quality and the complexity of the laws and procedures are evident.
it is essential to look at the good practices in Portugal, where electronic contracting has worked well and has facilitated public contracting.
An effective European public procurement represents a privileged means of controlling the public deficit and of increasing growth.
For this reason, it will be necessary to have a stable and predictable legal framework, less bureaucratic procedures to attract SMEs and defend social and environmental values.

That is why I express satisfaction for the intentions that Commissioner Barnier presents us here for the public procurement review, as still this year, as one of the 12 priorities of the Single Market Act. Thank you.
I would like to congratulate my colleague Rula and everyone who collaborated with her.
Important in the domain of public contracts is the issue of electronic public contracting.
Unfortunately, the objectives proposed by the European Union, 50% of the electronic procedure dedications in 2010 failed, finding in the average values scarce 5%.
Only a few countries, like my case, Portugal, have succeeded in this domain.

The advantages of electronic public contracting are evident and were mentioned here. It allows to replace the expensive access processes with the simple consultation of the electronic platform, that is, it reduces many costs for companies, especially for

small and medium-sized companies, the spread of the internet and the ease of receiving the parts, processual, increase the number of suppliers, increasing competition and allowing to buy better, makes the process of the issuance of public contracts

easier and more flexible, simplifies access to European Union public contracts, especially for small and medium-sized companies, thus facilitating the participation in the public market of these important economic engines.

In this sense, we salute and encourage the European Commission to reinforce the mechanisms in order to transform the electronic public transaction into an increasingly comprehensive reality. Thank you very much.

We are living decisive hours for the destiny of Europe. And if the situation quickly passed before everyone's eyes, from a problem of the Greeks or the Portuguese to a problem of great European dimension, the truth is that the lack of solutions and its delay has not produced any effect in the rapid degradation of the situation.
The search for solutions directed to the States, in detriment of truly European solutions, allowed the markets to continue to speculate on sovereign debts and imposed deadlines and
absolutely impossible that some States are trying to achieve with measures of an unimaginable brutality applied on people, companies and the public sector.

It is absolutely inescapable a common solution, already found for the risk of European sovereign debts, that removes the pressure from the markets and speculation and gives time for the adjustment that is essential to be made.
Without that, what we will have in the end will be countries that will continue without means to pay the creditors, destroyed economies and a lot, a lot of suffering.

to the colleagues of Relatores Sombra, with whom I had a fruitful collaboration, and I also thank the Relatores of the partners of the four commissions involved. These partners are a valuable contribution to this report.
We received 400 amendments and we elaborated 47 commitments that were all approved.
This shows the importance and interest of this topic of new skills and jobs.
After all, it is about preparing the human resources of Europe, anticipating the needs of the labor market in the next decade.
The key strategy for the elaboration of the report was to reformulate the common ideas to avoid repetitions and ensure the coherence of the report.
I think that this objective was achieved.
We all know that the crisis that currently affects us has highlighted the fragility of the European economic and social model, as well as annulled several of the progress achieved in the past.
Since the first effects of the crisis began to be felt in the labor markets in 2008, Europe has already lost more than 5 million jobs.
Today, almost 23 million people have no jobs.
Young unemployment is even more frightening. The young unemployment rate is close to 21% and represents more than twice the overall unemployment rate.
On the other hand, in all Member States, the unemployment rate varies with the level of qualifications.
This means that people with higher qualifications find a job more easily.
We also know that in the near future, the needs in terms of skills, competences and qualifications will increase in all types and levels of profession.
In this context, Europe faces four challenges. First, the creation of jobs. Second, the need to keep itself competitive.
Then, the sustainability of social security systems. And finally, the difficulty in finding people with the right skills to meet the job offers.

This report has a double objective. First, to highlight the need to act quickly in order to eliminate the gaps in competencies in Europe. Second, to better anticipate the needs of the labour market in competencies.

Various measures are highlighted for this. First, to ensure the availability of qualified labor, it is necessary to improve basic skills, as well as skills in science, innovation, information and communication technologies, as well as in foreign languages.
As I have already mentioned, the needs of skills must be identified early, on a minimum of 10 years horizon.
Do you know the potential of a new sustainable economy, the green economy and the need for investment in ecological qualifications?
Then, participation in training throughout life and professional qualification and reducing school dropout should be increased.
Another important issue is the mutual recognition of diplomas and professional qualifications and the urgency to advance with this recognition.
Fourth, we call attention to the link that should exist between educational institutions and the needs of the labor market.
The internships must be of high quality and supervised by tutors, so that they can lead to a job and end up with any abuse of the situation of the interns.
It also highlights the role of social partners and social dialogue.
The report also proposes measures to promote the search and creation of employment.
We have a future ahead and we have to create jobs.
and small and medium-sized companies play a decisive role in this.

It is also necessary to reinforce the single market to facilitate the free circulation of workers and hence the need for the coordination of social security systems so that workers can see their rights guaranteed, especially the portability of pensions.

Finally, the issue of flexibility of the labor market. To improve the functioning of the labor market, the rules of safety and safety must be adapted to the socio-economic contexts of each member state. Thank you very much.
Thank you, Mr. President. I would like to thank all the colleagues who have intervened in this live debate.
All colleagues had very useful interventions and contributed to a very constructive discussion on an ambitious agenda at a time when we are experiencing a serious crisis.

In fact, this discussion is taking place exactly on the eve of the European Council's implementation, which will show whether or not there is political will to overcome the difficulties we are experiencing and whether there is political will
to deepen our economic coordination and to have a unified and united will to carry forward the ambition on this agenda.

new jobs in the next decade, new jobs that will lead to the young people who are unemployed today and those who are graduating to have hope in the labor market, to have hope in an inclusive labor market that will give them the answer to their

ambition of dignification through work and that also have the opportunity to be in a permanent dynamism to accompany the challenges of a globalized economy and with a dynamic that has no parallel in the last generations.

Therefore, our ambition is to create jobs, to increase the economic growth, not only to give an answer to those who are unemployed in the aftermath of the crisis, but also to those who will enter the labor market.

to the great challenges that are there with the green economy, with the services in the health sector, with the services in the transport sector, the accommodation sector, which require from all of us a different vision, an intelligent vision and an inclusive vision of the labour market.
Thank you very much.

Thank you, Mrs. President. What was said today in the Council's statement is that, for technical reasons, democracy should be sacrificed in the European semester. But what we are talking about is a political issue. And the question I ask is whether there could be political coordination without democracy.
Where is the European Parliament's scrutiny?
Where is the national parliaments' scrutiny of their great budget options?

But if the issue is technical, as it was said here, then we are talking about a variable technique. Because we know how the Council substantially relieved the conditions of the four countries that are on the waiting list, France, Italy, Hungary, Spain. The same did not do with the countries that are under rescue.
So, what intergovernmental model is this, that allows Germany to give opinions about Portugal, but does not allow Portugal to give opinions about Germany?
And, Mr. Minister, please, I ask you to pay attention to this. No problem of democratic legitimacy is solved by asking the deputies to consult the information on the internet.
This is a problem of infallibility, not a problem of democratic exclusion, which is what we are here to talk about. Thank you very much.

Thank you, Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, colleagues. A first word to congratulate the Ardennes report on the quality and opportunity of this report and also Mr. Commissioner Andor for the initiatives announced.
Poverty is a very serious problem that requires a quick and effective action to stop the phenomenon that currently reaches more than 80 million Europeans.
The serious crisis we are going through has come to worsen this situation and make the times we live in dramatic, as Commissioner Andor said.
The number of unemployed people is constantly increasing and we all know that the lack of employment is a passport for poverty and social exclusion.
This panorama requires resources, willpower and a lot of commitment from the European Commission and the Member States.
If this does not happen, the goal of removing 20 million European citizens from poverty during this decade will not be achieved.
That is why I strongly support the initiative of the Platform Against Poverty, which is a very important instrument to ensure social justice.
But no one has doubts that the best antidotes to poverty and social exclusion are the creation of jobs and the promotion of economic growth.
President, access to the internet must be considered as a new fundamental right of citizens and not just as a mere commercial object, because of this right
It depends on essential things such as freedom of expression, access and sharing of information, access and sharing of culture and knowledge, as well as democratic and media pluralism.

And that is why this access cannot be subject to speculative tariffs or contracts that allocate free choice and the possibility of easily changing suppliers, particularly in the world of mobile telecommunications, as we also know.
Active citizenship requires that a complete and transparent information is provided.
The blockade to the use of the internet is not only exclusive to political regimes that are afraid of their people.
It can also happen as a result of economic options, by the supply of privileges to special clients and it is a treatment less equal to clients that are not so profitable.
That is why I support the Parliament in clearly putting itself next to the neutrality of the internet and the defence of its total abrogation.
Let's be honest.
We have been taking medication for three years to get out of the crisis and the situation is getting worse day by day.
Instead of healing, we created two fatal vicious circles.
The first one is between banks and states.
In Europe, the failure of a State is more easily discussed today than that of a large bank. But we must continue to hope that the banks finance the States and that the States save their banks.
This spiral has to be broken.
The Commission must advance with European legislation that protects the bank's crisis' contributors.
But it is also vital to protect the debt of the states from the attacks of the speculators.

And for this, it is urgent and already late to prepare the coordinated sovereign debt issuance, call it Eurobonds or Stability Bonds, and guarantee it through robust instruments of community character and not intergovernmental.
In addition, we must also review the European Central Bank's involvement.
But the second vicious circle results from the argument that some states are rich because they are virtuous, while others are poor because they sinned.
This narrative is politically explosive and technically wrong.

It ignores the essential fact that a market and a single currency, built by political choice among the unequal, necessarily aggravates the unbalancing competitiveness between the centre and the periphery.
And this is what must be addressed in economic governance.
No, Mr. Rompuy, through sanctions that promote the smuggling of salaries and income with the control of one country over another.
through the involvement of the countries with the most deficits, as well as those with the most existing ones, in order to make productivity converge through investment, education and science.
Sanctions have only generated unemployment, disappointment and a wave of suffering that we can't get out of.

Thank you very much, Mr. President. Madam Commissioner, integrated maritime policy defends a coordinated approach to the management and governance of the oceans, seas and coasts, in a global and coherent perspective of all European policies related to the sea.

Having a global perspective and an integrated approach implies the interaction of European policies linked to the Maroc and demands a better governance through greater involvement in the process of making European decisions.
The success and relevance of this policy has been demonstrated over the last few years through the various initiatives funded through preparatory actions and pilot projects.
Integrated maritime policy should therefore continue to benefit from adequate financing during the next years of the current financial programming period.
In this sense, I defend an adequate financing until 2013, not only to consolidate the previous projects, and I support the definition of a stable framework relative to the objectives of this program.

The issues of politics, governance, sustainability and maritime surveillance are, for obvious reasons, issues that particularly interest some regions of the European Union, such as the ultra-peripheral regions.

The eruptions in regions, with the exception of French Guiana, being small and small, depend on a reduced number of economic activities, and in which the activities related to the sea and fishing take special importance.
In addition, the ultra-peripheral regions contribute to the European Union having the largest exclusive economic zone in the world.

RUP represents more than half of the European Union's exclusive economic zone, with 15 to 25 million square kilometres, which, together with coastal regions, are fundamental to the economic growth of the European Union and its member states.
A programme such as the one of Integrated Maritime Policy should benefit these regions, favouring the transnational coordination of maritime policies and relevant international cooperation.
It is therefore necessary to guarantee a continuous and sufficient financing, not only for the next two years, but also and above all for the next financial framework from 2014.
Stop taking advantage of the opportunity when it comes to integrated maritime policy to underline the enormous potential that the Atlantic and Insular dimensions bring to the European Union.

The Atlantic, being the Western maritime border of Europe, also establishes its connection to the Americas of the North and the South and Africa, providing a strategic dimension for Europe, indispensable in the architecture of a maritime policy elaborated with the eyes set on the future.

And it is thinking about the future that integrated maritime policy, in addition to promoting the articulation of maritime activities, must place in the first line of its priorities the potential of the Atlantic in its three-dimensional dimension based on science and technology.

The research of the Atlantic's medium-term crisis, the deep sea and the marine funds constitutes a new frontier whose potential exists in biotechnology and mineral resources and is of incalculable value for the knowledge economy.
The Union should therefore take advantage of the privileged position of the Azores and the excellence of its oceanographic department to install there a deep sea observatory. Thank you.
Enough of this path.
When the diagnosis is wrong, the remedies don't work.
and in the case of the Eurozone, the excessive medicines have led to death.
The successive miraculous solutions that were proposed were also discredited by the markets.
the Financial Stabilization Fund, the successive shares of the Stability and Growth Pact, the Troika's revenue in the countries under this program.
Blind, ungrowing discipline created a recessive wave between economies that were totally interconnected, and that was why they were contaminated with failures and unemployment.
And at the hands of the markets, that is, the notation agencies and speculators, governments fall one after the other and the solvent countries become insolvent.

Changing the treaties now is one more step in this disastrous trajectory, with a gravante. Let's risk destroying what is left of national sovereignty, putting the countries at the hands of the European Court of Justice.
No, we don't need to change the treaties.
In this emergency we are in, we need to make two decisions.
First of all, we need to realize a real agenda for growth and sustained cohesion.
Where is the Agenda 2020?
Where is the release order?
Where are the project-bonds for the European Structural Investments?
Secondly, we need to protect the sovereign debt.
Of course, the euro bonds are necessary, but in this emergency we are in, it is urgent that the European Central Bank, directly or indirectly, defends the sovereign debt against speculators.
not in an embarrassed way, but with a definitive position, decided as it competes with any central bank that defends its currency and the economy that supports it.
For this, it is not necessary to change the treaties, it is necessary political will and European conviction.
We will change the treaty when we have removed all the lessons from the current crisis. And there are few lessons to be removed. But this is not the moment. Thank you.
Mr. President and Mr. Commissioner Dali, the first forum of the unique market idea that comes from the Greek report took place in Krakow
was rich in content and fruitful in the debate carried out by the Polish Presidency with European, national, regional, local and civil society authorities.
We have a roadmap, drawn up in the communication of the April 12 Commission, with the 12 levers.
It needs to be passed into law, as well as the strategy of the other 38 priorities identified in the Act for a Unified Market.
For a market to exist, trust is necessary.
The trust of citizens and consumers cannot be seen as a given data, it lacks to be stimulated, fed.

The Unique Market is not just a purchase and sale operation. It involves horizontal policies such as health, social protection and consumers, the right to work, the environment and sustainable development.
The UNFCCC Forum must become an emblematic event of the European Union with an annual event and with a diversified and increasingly participatory public.
Thank you very much, Mr. President. I think we are at a time of balance in these crises and austerity policies that have affected so many countries, and also the so-called structural reforms.
And it is in this context that I think we cannot stop seeing how they have generated so much social commotion.
and has generated social commotion not only in the countries with the greatest difficulties, in the southern countries, not only in the so-called peaks, but also in other contexts in Europe.
Last week we had the biggest strike in Portugal, both in the public and private sectors.

But if we look at what happened today in the United Kingdom, we can see that we have been witnessing the biggest strike ever, especially if we take into account that people went out on the streets as well as they did in Portugal.
and we hope that on Friday a great demonstration in Brussels.

What this proves, Mr. President, and what the strikes prove in the outings of people on the streets, is that the causes and problems we have faced are common and that is why the reaction is also common.
The crisis of the European Union is infecting all member states, reaching unbelievable proportions.

We are witnessing a chaos in the financial markets and the growing inability to ensure the essential financing of the activity of our small and medium-sized companies, even those that are healthy, leading them to despair, failure and unemployment.
It is a spiral that feeds the recession and is destroying the economy and society.

No one denies the need for rigorous budgetary discipline, deep re-structurations and more economic governance. But these are necessary conditions that, in the short term, are no longer enough to counter the ongoing degradation in the Union.

And if the truth is that there are political procedures that will determine the employment and growth without which we will never be able to control sovereign debts, the central issue today is to guarantee the financing of our companies and our economies without which the Union will prosper.
So, more than ever, more than the review of the treaties, we need today a strong and safe intervention from the European Central Bank.
Thank you very much, Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner. We are here today, all together, in the middle of a resolution with a set of very important demands in terms of intervention.
We are talking about the World Day Against HIV and AIDS and this assessment of the 2009 resolution and communication is fundamental.
It is fundamental precisely because of things that have already been mentioned
We repeat ourselves because, unfortunately, there is still room for repetition, which means that there is a lot to do.
There are many new cases diagnosed every year in Europe and in the European Economic Area. A 2010 report talks about more than 25,000 new cases.
If we consider the neighboring countries, we are talking about more than 100,000 new cases.
And if we think that there are things that can't get any worse, they can always get worse.

And one of the questions I want to make very clear here is about the disinvestment that has been made in the health sector as a result of the economic and financial crisis that we are currently experiencing.
and this has seriously affected the fundamental domains of the fight against HIV and AIDS.
That is why, Mr. Commissioner, I think that the Commission has a fundamental role to play here in asking the Member States to fulfill their obligations in these domains.

A second issue also has to do with the increase in discrimination, evidenced by the economic and social crisis. The discrimination of workers who have lost their jobs because they are carriers of this virus.
That is why prevention, treatment and care should be the same for everyone, regardless of sex, age, regardless of the region where they live.
and I hope we can implement these measures with the support of the Commissioner. Thank you.
Welcome to this Parliament, Mr Draghi.
We are living in special and dramatic circumstances and they require certain and urgent measures.

The spiral between the State's debt and the banks' debt must be broken. But at this moment, the priority is to defend the States, to ensure that the countries in the Eurozone and the Euro itself are not destroyed by rating agencies and speculators.
In the report we will approve, Tremosa and Basel, we have proposals to rethink the architecture of the Eurozone, to create Eurobonds and a European treasury. But all this takes time.
Right now we are talking about an emergency and in this context the only solution is in the hands of the European Central Bank.
Technically, the European Central Bank knows what needs to be done.
Today, he should not be inhibited in his intervention and in his action by limited interpretations of his mandate.
Its mandate is to safeguard the euro, not to deal with inflation.
At this moment, there is no doubt. Saving the Euro and doing what is necessary is what this Parliament and the citizens expect from the European Central Bank.

By privileging relations with the population in general and with civil society organizations in particular, we will be giving greater objectivity and greater effectiveness to our neighborhood policy, which is exclusively based on the universal values we defend and share.
However, I underline that the European Union does not intend to impose a model or a predefined formula for political reforms in third countries.
But when the money of our contributors is at stake, we should give more to those who are doing more, in the approach to the values we believe in.
This means that the faster a country progresses in its internal reforms, the more support it will get from the European Union.

The policy of neighborhood is now based on the defense of the prosecution of common values and on the commitment to democracy, human rights, the rule of law and good governance.
But this search implies a greater responsibility.
Our partners are called to have more responsibility in the process. That is why we defend the principles of greater differentiation, greater conditionality and the so-called more for more.

By taking a position of approach to our partners, from the bottom up, and the policies made to the measure, what we call the bottom-up approach and the tailor-made policies, we have made the development and institutional capacity more effective.

The institutional building that we want to defend and that is based on the rule of law and the democratic process, we want to implement as soon as possible in societies, economies and communities of our neighbors.

countries, improving women's and children's rights, building and deepening the principles of freedom, whether of expression, association, religious belief, press, choice, etc.

European politics of neighborhood without including the ultra-parifereic regions as active borders of Europe in different parts of the world.

rights and guarantees, the safeguarding of European citizens, which are protected by European legislation and then are surpassed when legislation from other countries overlaps European legislation.

between European citizens and European institutions. And therefore, if citizens accept that European institutions can be guardians of their personal data in so many different domains, from health issues to other issues such as those of companies,

the decrease of the ties of trust that exist between their citizens and their institutions. And in this sense, Madam Commissioner, please answer us, to what extent can we guarantee that European legislation overcomes the legislation of third countries?

A year ago we witnessed the tragic combination between an earthquake, a tsunami and a nuclear industrial accident, all in sequence.
Today we pay a sincere tribute to the many thousands of Fukushima victims.
Honoring the victims is telling them that we have learned the lesson. We must learn to deal with natural disasters. We have the obligation to avoid them with the nuclear weapons.
But unfortunately, that seems to be not the truth.
a year after Fukushima and new nuclear power plants are still being built.
A year after Fukushima, new nuclear power plants are still planned.
Unfortunately, Japan has the memory of the tragedies that last. Hiroshima, Nagasaki... And we Europeans also have the memory of a tragedy that lasts. Chernobyl.
Fukushima forces us to reopen a debate that should never have been closed, the debate on nuclear energy.
A year ago, nuclear energy was unquestionable for the Japanese. Today, two thirds of the Japanese do not want it.
They know it costs lives, they know that this cost has no price. On the contrary, it is a cost that increases from generation to generation.
The stubborn policy in favor of nuclear is the policy of arrogance.
Also here in Europe we have a majority of public opinion against nuclear and yet nothing seems to change.
Today there are 320,000 refugees in Japan. Of these, 100,000 will never be able to return home.
What was once familiar is now dangerous. What was once comfort is now ruin.
It is the ruin of a building or a house with radioactive vegetation. It is the ruin of the soil or contaminated water.
Fukushima cannot be visited as other ruins are visited, such as a Mayan or a Roman ruin. However, like these, Fukushima also portrays a civilization. And the Fukushima ruin portrays our civilization.
the one that chose to include in its development model a deadly technology.

As already mentioned, diabetes affects more than 30 million people in Europe
These are the numbers of an epidemic.
And that is why I understand that it is justified to make a specific resolution regarding diabetes, even more so because it is the first time that this Parliament has been dedicated to this issue.

It is the result of a collective work and it is a work that does not cancel the work that has been done on chronic diseases, on the contrary, it reinforces this capacity that we have to intervene together.
We have about 325 thousand annual deaths associated with diabetes because we know that diabetes is the main cause of, for example, heart attacks, blindness, amputations, failure of vital organs.
And for this data we have two options, in my understanding.
The first is to say that it is not that serious, that we can live well with this and that each government deals with itself.
The second is to say that the absence of a European strategy in this domain is part of the problem.
I understand that we have a lot to do on this side.
and we have a lot to do in precocious diagnosis, coordination, investment in research.

Mr. President, I would like to say that we are very happy to have taken steps to integrate Serbia into the European Union.

This is very important because the experience of countries like Portugal, Spain or Greece, which were countries that lived dictatorships and had a set of very serious problems, is the experience that European integration was the way to consolidate democracy.
And that's why Serbia also deserves this opportunity.
I would like to give a note here that is a little different from the one given by my colleagues.
I know and I care a lot about the minorities, but we must not forget the Serbian majority. It is essential that the Serbs themselves have a place in the European Union and a place of full right.

Thank you, Mr. President. Last week, Portugal voted on the last budgetary act, which is not a European treaty, it is good to mention it.

The vote in favour of the government's parties reflects the accumulation of decades and decades of stupidity and a typical attitude of the good student, a racist who does not think and obeys the bad teachers.

The budget consolidation is imposing almost unbearable demands on some European citizens.
However, every day there are fewer people who have to bear a bigger burden.
The tax burden is on workers, small and medium-sized companies, consumers, and, meanwhile, there is a completely unmeasured tax evasion.
The European Socialist Group wanted to know how much this evasion of tax value in the 27 countries. And they are worth 1 million of millions of euros. In English, one trillion euros.
This is more than the European Union spends on health.
This means that if we spent just a fifth of this investment, the investment would rise in Europe from 2.7% of GDP to 3.5%. We are talking about an exceptionally high value.

And the meaning of the resolution we are going to approve, initiated by this Parliament, is precisely a very clear requirement to the Commission and the Council to accelerate the concrete action to combat tax evasion and fraud.

This means concrete initiatives of fiscal cooperation within the European Union, with our neighboring countries, in particular Switzerland, but negotiated by the Commission and not country to country, in a bilateral way.
This means reforming and harmonizing the accounting rules, increasing transparency and reporting.
This clearly means reactivating the fundamental issue of combating fraud and tax evasion through tax havens.
Europe is not a minor shareholder.
Europe is a great partner in the international context
Europe has the obligation to, in the G20, clearly defend a common fight against fraud and tax evasion.

Without this, we lose credibility among our citizens and, therefore, my last words are in this debate to encourage the Commission and Council to start an effective fight against fraud and tax evasion. Thank you very much.

Thank you, Mr. President. The reason for this regulation is to impose limits on the rates of mobile phones charged to European consumers when in roaming, with its main objective to end roaming in the European space from 2016 onwards.
Our citizens are now benefiting from a decrease in prices in calls, SMS and data.
If today there are operators that charge 3 euros per megabyte, from July the maximum price they can charge is 70 cents per megabyte, passing this value to 20 cents in 2014.
Regarding the calls received, the maximum price that can be charged will be 0.08€ this year and 0.05€ in 2014.
In July 2012, a family with two mobile users raised, as the Commissioner said, 200 euros in their bill.
Second benefit, greater quality of information for consumers.
From the summer, the operators are forced to inform the consumers of the prices when they travel abroad.
Until now, the obligation was only for the European space.
Third advantage, the possibility of more operators entering the market, which means an increase in competition that will stimulate better services and better prices.

Finally, in the near future, the consumer will be able to have two contracts, one for services in the national territory and another for services abroad, keeping the same number of mobile phones and having only one bill.
will also be offered to the consumer, to our citizen, the possibility of contracting with any European operator that offers the best price.

without promoting growth, especially in those states that are most affected by the financial crisis. But sometimes, when I hear some colleagues here, I get the feeling that they think that there may still be growth with excessive deficits and poor public accounts.

the Portuguese Europeanization, at least in terms of values, was not a negative thing. And so, rejects this idea of trying to humiliate or try to reduce any people.
