This is a trap, Mr. Commissioner, a trap of a Europe that is a hostage of governments and a Europe that is a hostage of financial interests.
We must not let people live in fear, because it is not a way of living. Europe can be something else. You are wise. There is no lack of money, there is lack of shame.

Mr. President, Mr. Minister Vaman, the first thing I would like to declare is that it is unfortunate that in a debate of this importance, the vice-president of the Commission and the high representative, Mrs. Ástame, is not present.
In any case, we have the pleasure of working once again with Minister Vaman, who made a statement here that I fully appreciate.

I would like to give a word of comfort and solidarity to the Guinean people, who have been, basically, the people of Guinea-Bissau, a people systematically massacred by democratic instability, political instability and great insecurity.
The poverty that has been systematically affected by these evils.

I would also like to say that the PPP, in its Presidency, has been following this issue since the beginning. And it is also unfortunate that the European Parliament, only after a month, manages to have a debate on this matter.
This has to do with the invisibility of the Guinean people and the Guinean Christian.

And this invisibility is only the fact that, unlike other matters, which are also very serious, there are no large economic interests here that motivate the European, American and world powers to debate the situation of the Guinean people.
But I must say, if it is necessary an external motive, if it is not enough to have poverty and political instability for us to have a humanitarian and global political action,
Unless the situation of drug trafficking, which is rampant in Guinea and directly affects the European and American peoples, was a reason for us to insist on this.
And so I ask the European Union to be stronger.

There is no doubt that the Resolution 2048, the decisions of the European Union, the Community of the Portuguese Language Countries, the African Union, but perhaps not yet, the Community of the States of West Africa, are and will be in the right direction.
But resolutions are not enough, actions are needed.
We must be more firm, more effective, together with the States that have the capacity to intervene in Guiné-Bissau.
This is our obligation.
I believe that the European Union is responding well to the principles, but not as it should be in the practical instruments of the field operation. This is what I ask the Council and the Commission.

President, President of the Exercises, Mr. Commissioner, dear colleagues, globalization brought with it an disproportionate growth of the financial sector, whose transactions are today, as we know, 70 times higher than global wealth.
Opacity, frequent transactions, high remuneration and high risk have not only characterized the world we live in today, but also have been fundamental reasons for the crisis we have been through.
However, this crisis came to ask for accounts and efforts much more to ordinary citizens than to the sector that had caused it.
Thus, today, this moment is important.

It is important, and I would personally like to obtain a situation in which the tax was generalized in all the countries of the European Union and then extended to the rest of the world through an active participation of the Commission and the European Union in general in the context of the G20,
I would like to cover all products without exception
I would like it to serve as a basis for the necessary reinforcement of the European Union's own resources.
In the short term, we have to accept commitments, but we must not lose the sense of where we have to go.
And this can only be achieved with a clear identification of these objectives by this Parliament, by the Commission and with a great spirit of commitment by the Council.

This is what European citizens expect from us today and I can only thank the role of ANI Polimata, who was tireless in this process, as well as all those who managed to overcome the divergences to reach a common position.

Thank you Mr. President, thank you colleague Podimata. Today we discussed here for the first time the tax on financial transactions and to be approved is the first sign that speculation is not totally impudent in this crisis in which we live.
This House and European institutions must respond to people and not to financial markets.
For decades, financial markets lobbies managed to govern the world without opposition and without any problem.
It is obvious to us that during 2008 and 2012 the crisis of the speculative financial market was at the root of most of the problems we have experienced.
And yet, these speculative financial markets managed not only to do nothing, but to transfer directly from the citizens' pockets to these speculative markets.

We have fought for this for many years, Mr. President, but it was only when the people all over Europe started saying enough that finally there was some initiative by the institutions that govern the European Union.
And so that is the answer we must give to citizens. It is the first sign we must give them.
The citizens of Europe, who have everything paid, do not deserve to be disrespected.
And therefore, this proposal is not complete, it is not perfect, it will not solve the whole problem of financial speculation, but it is an important sign.
We have been, not us, the European leaders, asking for forgiveness to the financial markets
should apologize to the people who have been affected.
And to finish, Mr. President, a famous politician today is one of those markets that govern us without ever having been elected.

I sincerely hope that governments give people a sign of trust and I sincerely hope that with this approval and the positive vote of colleagues we will start talking about justice and solidarity in Europe
Colleagues, get the courage, let's make this project happen.
Thank you Mr. President. The tax on financial transactions should work as a way to control and discourage speculative activities of high risk in the financial sector.
It aims to reduce speculation and increase healthy competition, base of the single market and also generate revenue.

The Podimata report tried to bring the initial proposal of the European Commission to the well-known United Kingdom Stamp Tax. Thus we made this proposal more attractive to the reluctant member states.
We hope that the Council also understands the message.

If the Commission proposed that the tax would be applied to transactions of financial institutions located in the territory of the European Union, it is now intended that the transactions of European assets, even if not European, are also taxed.
This measure will increase the base of revenue and reduce the leaks.
It is hoped that the revenue from the tax will be considered as a source of resources of the Union or of the States, reducing the taxes of the Member States, a matter yet to be decided.
I conclude, Mr. President, by congratulating the reporter for her work quality and I hope that this symbolic text
Thank you, Mr. President. This weekend we had another request to save the private bank.
continue to say the same argument, which is to avoid the contagion in the Eurozone. And what I ask is if we learn nothing. Greece, Portugal, Ireland and now Spain, and yet the contagion continues.
But what kind of contagion is this that is destroying us?

This policy doesn't work, we should know it. It's the same governors who say there's no money for culture, education, health, public goods, that when banks ask for it or markets, they make it appear almost by miracle.
This economic policy is not a remedy, it is a deadly poison for growth, for employment, for the European economy, for the social Europe.
The markets are in control and the governments are obeying and blackmailing the people. And that is what the governments are doing with Greece at this time, in the electoral period.

I sincerely hope that it is good for all of us, the Greek people, not to be blackmailed on the next Sunday and that they give us a lesson, because this recipe, Mrs. President, is a recipe for disaster. Thank you very much.
Thank you very much, Mr. President. Unfortunately, the proposals we discussed here today confirm the prohibition of anti-crisis policies in the Eurozone and still concretize the logic of the budget.

There are some declarations of intentions, but they are very shy. I refer, for example, to the letter for one day to be able to start thinking about ways to define a possible legislation for the hypothetical introduction of the Eurobonds.
The problem is that that day is only when all the problems in the Eurozone are solved and it takes a long time to get there.
We support some aspects of this proposal, but at this rate everything will be too little and too late.
Putting a country under legal protection implies the maintenance of taxes and amounts, as well as the priority of new loans. In other words,
member states that honor their debt, but remove from them all the instruments that can allow them to grow and find the resources to do so.

Let's be frank with each other. The only legal protection that exists in these proposals and that is provided is for the creators. But even those will not be resolved, because it is not effective for them.

As we saw in Greece, Ireland, Portugal and now Spain, this means condemning countries to recession, unemployment and insolvency. And I end, Mr. President, by saying that the aggravation of these situations and its drag on other economies brings us closer to a point of no return.

Faced with the complete failure of austerity, the European Commission or the German government propose the same policy, but in a Deovardose regime. It is neoliberal fanaticism that is killing the Euro.
Thank you very much, Mr. President. With the extremely limited time we have, I would like to tell the Commission that it can count on this
in a work that is effective in the sense of the solidity of the Eurozone and of Europe, but that is only achieved when the initiatives that focus on discipline, we

We have managed to add the conditions for a balanced share of gains and sacrifices between the different member states and between the different citizens and a hope that we will get out of the crisis we are going through.
For this hope to exist, we need other initiatives. And these are the ones that this Parliament is trying to fulfill. An initiative aimed at investment, growth and control
of the sovereign debt that has been the heel of what is evidently the weakness of the economic systems of some of the member countries.
Mr. Commissioner, you can count on us, Mr. Councilor, Mrs. President, you can count on us, but the agenda must be comprehensive. It can't be an agenda that makes
discipline the condition for everything else to follow, nor does discipline the alpha and omega of our European proposals.

Our citizens expect that from us, they can count on the Parliament and I want to thank again to the colleagues, to the rapporteurs, to Mr. Gozesc, who is another rapporteur, and to all the colleagues who, as shadow rapporteurs or merely active elements in the construction of this project, were able to contribute
for a more balanced, more solid project of the Parliament and that I hope deserves the respect, the capacity for dialogue and the spirit of construction and commitment that has so far
Thank you very much, Mr. President, thank you very much, Mrs. President, thank you very much, Mr. Commissioner.

Thank you very much, Mrs. President. In addition to thanking everyone who contributed to this result, I would like to ask that the final vote be postponed so that we can negotiate immediately with the level of trilogies.
The European Union confronts itself today with three agendas. The growth agenda, the bank management agenda and the sovereign debt management agenda.
and to treat the European semester implies including these three dimensions.
Regarding the issue of growth, I think that at this moment it is important to underline that the recommendations of the Commission cannot only affect
countries with a deficit. They also have to influence countries with excesses. And if some have to crush their internal search, others have to free them.

I also think that, at the level of growth, it is essential that the Commission controls the recommendations of the so-called Troika. Because when a country enters into recession, it cannot continue to crush its public investment, to crush the public expenditure, as if nothing had happened.
Troika has to have its revenue revised and adjusted according to the results. And I want to tell you, Mr. Commissioner, that we have approved here in the
the Parliament, the need to immediately launch an instrument for growth and for the anti-cycle activity of the 1% GDP of the European Union for 10 years.
A second dimension is the one that is now called the banking union. We asked the Parliament to do this two years ago, in a June 2010 report. It is now being realized.

A third dimension is the dimension of sovereign debt. Without it, there is no stability in Europe. And I also want to tell you that today we approve the Tupac, but we introduce in the Tupac, beyond austerity,

some of the other dimension that has been missing. And it is the immediate constitution of a redemption fund, using the German terminology, so that the sovereign debt, which exceeds 60%, can be managed in common.

This is a legislative text and we await the good support of the Commission to this Parliamentary initiative, so that we can control the completely threatening spiral that is destroying the European Union. Thank you very much.

Thank you very much, Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, dear colleagues. Now that we intend to discuss a growth pact, it is essential not to forget the citizens and consumers, and, in the end, the human and social dimension

that gives it body and that was the theme of one of the three reports on the Single Market Act of 2001. Why should any growth pact take into account the sacrifices and social benefits that are linked to it?

as important as an internal market test, will be to make a social impact test of all measures taken to achieve a single market. A test, yes, an exam that allows us to measure the progress achieved for the benefit of citizens of the European Union.
Since 2008, Europe has lost more than 6 million jobs.
In my country, Portugal, the economy suffers a contraction that has no precedent and the unemployment of men, women and young people reaches historical records.
According to the forecast of Banco de Portugal, the situation will worsen in the next two years.
It is in this context that we support and salute the initiative of the new employment package and congratulate Commissioner Andor.
Now and always insisting on the basic premise of the need for economic growth, the Member States will really have to focus their efforts on creating employment.

The means for this must be through subsidies to the contracting that creates new jobs, by reducing the tax burden on work and support for the creation of new companies and entrepreneurship, but also to small and medium-sized companies that maintain jobs.

It is necessary that the national employment policies must bear in mind that the areas with the greatest potential for creating jobs are health, information and communication technologies and the green economy.
It is necessary, as it is said in the communication, to reduce the gap between the qualifications provided by education and the skills required by the labor market.
On the other hand, one of the solutions to combat unemployment is through the mobility of workers.

It is also crucial that the use of structural funds for the creation of jobs and the practical importance of the EUROS portal as an instrument for the excellence of recruitment and job offers in Europe.
Finally, social governance must be on the agenda because our citizens are eagerly waiting for concrete results. Thank you very much.

Thank you very much, Mr. President. Mr. Commissioner, it is true that it has been six months since this scandal with the PIP occurred. And the most unbelievable thing is that, during ten years, a private company may have managed
to operate in the market and have introduced silicone implants that should be intended for the construction and manufacture of pads and were used in women in 71 countries.
This affected many hundreds of millions of women, as already mentioned, and it is estimated that about 500,000.
We are talking about estimates because there were serious failures in this process. We know that what happened to this company is a criminal case, a fraud, a case of the court, but we also know

that there is a fraud that must be controlled by the courts and the courts will deal with it. But there is a legal flaw, a legal void and we must deal with it. We have responsibilities in this matter.

For 10 years we could not identify what the criminals could identify. Therefore, there was a void in terms of control, traceability, archives, records. Everything failed. But these gentlemen from this company were able to put into practice what we could not control.

In this process, there is not only the lack of information, which is very important, in fact, the lack of information in all matters related to breast implants, but also the humiliation of thousands of women and the humiliation, in particular, of those women who had to undergo tests to know if they had placed correct implants or not.

We are talking about a public health issue and we cannot be lazy in public health matters. We control so many unnecessary things. We even control the authenticity of the replacement parts in the cars. We recently approved a directive on this.

We have to control what is fundamental for people's lives. The review of the medical device directive is good news. It was the best news that we didn't have to do it. But now that we are going to do it, we have to apply

with traceability, transparency, control, sanctions, because unfortunately the sanctions, even if they are applied, will not be applied to the women who suffered from this problem and the States must assume full responsibility.
Thank you, President. I would like to say that for us the Council will take place at the end of June and that what is essential is that a European solution for this crisis is sought.
From our point of view, the problem so far is that we have dealt with each of the issues that are emerging, individually and in isolation.

It is time to have a global solution for Europe. A solution that goes through, as the President here very well made it clear, through more integration, through more cooperation, through greater approach to European policies and through revaluation of the community method.
It is essential that, on the one hand, stability is at growth, but that we do not abandon the concerns of stability.
We count on a global European response, not a split response for each State or region in difficulty.
The productive and more production possibilities caused considerable increases in milk produced, creating critical, dependent and low prices in the milk and dairy markets.

In many regions with strong productive potential, these excedents were placed at a high price in the market of other countries, causing even greater pressure on low-priced producers in those countries.

This happened, for example, with French milk, sold in France at the double price of the one sold in Galicia. And the producers, with the increased cost of raw materials and production factors, saw today their capacity to resist low prices being extremely reduced.

This is a bad proclamation for many explorations and many productive territories in Europe and it seems to be also a clear proclamation of what may come to be the future without quotas and without instruments of regulation of adequate supply.

That is why there should be a circumstantial audit on the territorial impacts, in thousands of populations throughout the European Union, of the abduction of these instruments that we have today to regulate the supply.
Thank you Mr. President. I start by congratulating the colleague who is the reporter for this report.
It is a matter of extreme importance for Europe.
At a time when we are experiencing a serious economic, financial and social crisis, protecting intellectual property rights by fighting for falsified products is essential for the European economy.
This protection must reinforce the research's performance and promote innovation. It must ensure scientific and technological knowledge, contributing to the development of new products and services.
All this in the sense of generating growth and creating quality jobs.

Unfortunately, in recent years we have witnessed a significant increase in the violation of intellectual property rights in Europe, which represent annual losses, as already mentioned, of 250 million euros for companies and the destruction of 185 thousand jobs in the European space.

But besides these negative effects on the European economy, the violation of these rights is also a serious threat to the health and safety of European consumers, since many counterfeit products, such as food, cosmetics, medicines, etc.
are produced in non-regulated environments.
Therefore, the customs authorities of the European Union play a crucial role in preventing the entry of counterfeit products into the domestic market.
With the revision of the current regulation, it is intended to reinforce the control of the application of the legislation in question, to reinforce the legitimacy of its intervention, to increase
and legal clarity, adapting the provisions of the Regulation to the new realities and developments, thus contributing to a better protection of the economy and European consumers.
Intellectual property rights are thus a crucial priority to achieve the objectives of the 2020 Strategy in order to achieve intelligent, sustainable and inclusive growth. Thank you.

Thank you very much, Mr. President. In fact, the election of a new Egyptian president in the post-Mubarak era is good news. But we cannot be fooled. These presidential elections do not close in any way what is the transition process that is taking place in Egypt.

It was well mentioned that the dissolution of the Parliament days before the presidential elections puts several risks on the table. And in this case, the power that is concentrated in the Supreme Council of the
the Armed Forces is at least exaggerated. It has legislative power, reducing the power of the President and, in addition, it still has in its hands the definition of the changes in the Constitution.

All this puts us in some preoccupations, and should put us in some preoccupations, because the Egyptians are at risk of being hostages of military power and of the return to the past, with the lack of a fundamental element, which is the democratically elected parliament.
We should not make the change in Egypt, the Egyptians should,
but I think that we Europeans should be on the side of all the changes that propose the reposition of what is democratic legitimacy and of a democratically elected parliament. Thank you very much.

Thank you very much, Mrs. President. Dear colleagues, Mrs. Commissioner, I begin by congratulating the colleague, the rapporteur, Lara Comey, for the excellent work done in this report, which is of vital importance for the future of Europe.
In a world and in a society in an accelerated transformation, Europe needs an comprehensive, integrative, effective and updated system of normalization.
A system that guarantees the correct functioning of the domestic market, that improves the protection of consumers and their lives, but also that protects the environment, is essential.
As well as social inclusion and social interaction and communication of networks and systems, especially in the domain of new information and communication technologies.
As Professor Monti said in his report, A New Strategy for the Single Market, European normalization is essential for the governance of the internal market,
the need for the review of the European process of normalization, which maintains the advantages of the current system and which finds the right balance between European and national dimensions.

In this sense, the report we are discussing now follows and defends these objectives, which are the correct and appropriate ones. Ending the slowness and fragmentation that exist and that makes companies incur costs

of transaction and at higher unit costs, strengthen the participation of SMEs in the activities of normalization, particularly at the national level, as well as facilitate their access to these standards, strengthen also

On the other hand, the participation of the parties that represent the interests of society, such as consumers, environmentalists, workers, people with disabilities, maintaining financial support for European organizations created to represent public interests.

I conclude by saying that the approval of the current report will contribute to the relaunch of the European project, to European innovation, to the reinforcement and competitiveness of our companies. Thank you very much.
Thank you very much Mr. President, Mrs. Commissioner. The future Common Fisheries Policy should favor its environmental, economic and social sectors
in a synergistic and non-hierarchical way, in favor of sustainable development and in accordance with the objectives of intelligent, sustainable growth, including the E2020 strategy.
As a member of the Regime, I would like to highlight the particularity of some regions, such as the ultra-peripheries, whose economies are strongly dependent on the sector.

In these regions, the reform of the Common Fish Policy must seek to ensure the survival and prosperity of its future fleets of artisanal and small-scale fishing, safeguarding and thus defending the job that depends on them.

I agree with the position of the European Commission on the need for an adjustment of this policy and specific measures that should take into account the disparate realities of the fishing and aquaculture sector in the various coastal regions.

I defend that this policy focuses on regionalization as a form of governance through a reinforcement of the participation of the various parties interested so that it is possible in the future a more adequate response to the needs and sensitivities of each maritime basin.
We are reaching the decisive moments in which we will shape the new fishing policy in Europe. And we cannot fail.

The need and urgency to achieve sustainable balance in our marine resources, but also in revitalizing our coastal fishing communities and promoting its socio-economic level, in the modernization of the sector and in the supply of quality food, requires, as never before, food and courageous measures.
That is why we must make choices and prioritize objectives.

I proposed protection for the fragility of my region, proposing that the exploration of its resources be done taking into account the scientific data and giving priority to our coastal communities in their exploration and restricting external access to more than 100 miles to the existing fishing banks.
I proposed to safeguard the fishing capacity of our important fishing communities, rejecting proposals for transferable coasts.

I proposed that our communities had better intervention in the management of their fishing issues, with the creation of a regional consultative council more suitable for the regions of the peripheries. I hope that we can have a better future.

Taking into account what we know about the application of the third package and part of this issue has already been discussed today, regarding the delay in the transposition of its directives, or what seems to be the last information I have

that 18 Member States have been notified, probably this information is already out of date due to lack of transposition. The question I ask you is how do you see the possibility of, in the legislation that is being prepared, namely the
to include a device, an incentive, that conditions the presentation of PCIs, of common interest projects,

and condition the compliance of the third package obligations by the Member States. Or, on the contrary, do you understand that this is an extravagant mechanism and that it should be left only to the regular mechanisms of competition, Article 101,
and its members, all the intervention in this matter. Thank you very much.
the will of the Commission and the tolerance, the spirit of tolerance that has existed in this matter. But the question is to know if, being in preparation, legislation that can
to introduce an additional and much stronger conditionality, do you think that this conditionality is an abusive instrument or do you think that this conditionality would be acceptable?
I confess that I share a lot of the concern that was presented here initially, the democratic legitimacy and the democratic control that are related to this proposal
and banking supervision, because it is to clarify and to resolve an essential issue, which is the role of Parliament, the only institution democratically elected by citizens, directly.

But there is another concern that I also have, which is a fundamental concern, and it has to do with the following. Monetary policy instruments are controlled by the European Union. Monetary policy is the responsibility of the European Union.

Bank supervision is also the responsibility of the European Union. However, if everything goes wrong, if the banks go bankrupt, the responsibility for paying this bankruptcy remains with the national states.

This is not a problem of less importance, it is a problem of fund that is not resolved. And finally, I just want to mention that the fact that we continue to tie monetary policy to what is a secondary issue in the context in which we live, which is inflation, and not to the creation of employment and growth, as it should be. Thank you very much.

Thank you very much Mr. President. European leaders continue to exist in the budgetary discipline and I ask the budgetary discipline, so let's go to it. Because what exactly do we talk about when we talk about budgetary discipline?

In my opinion, budgetary discipline is respecting contracts with pensioners and not abandoning the state's commitments to the middle. In my opinion, budgetary discipline is respecting contracts of those who work and not inventing extraordinary taxes or cuts of subsidies.

The financial responsibility is to respect the health, education, culture commitments and not to close services or cancel half projects. Discipline is to put the banks in order and not to go and take the contributors to put in the hands of speculators to save their banks.
This is the budgetary discipline that I would like to see implemented in the European Union and not continue in this market party.

If you need an example, the budget that is being discussed in Portugal, the Troika mandate, is a perfect example. It violates all the commitments that any State must have with its citizens, so as not to violate the agreements made at the close door that are reuniting Europe and its countries.

Thank you very much, Mr. President, Mr. President of the Council, Mr. President of the Commission. First of all, I would like to congratulate myself on the results of the Council. Although it seems to me that the final decision is a little delayed in time,
The truth is that there is an advance
Now, just because I remember everything my colleague Cassio Lides said, I would like to ask only one question to the President of the Council. The countries that are under assistance,
countries that are in trouble have fought a lot so that there can be a retroactive application of the bank debts in their separation from the State debt.
This apparently was not accepted.
But we heard yesterday declarations from the highest German authorities and the highest French authorities saying that they would treat Ireland with a special situation.
What I ask is whether the Council approved any decision to treat Ireland differently from the one that is reserved to countries like Portugal, Greece, Spain and others.
Dear colleagues, Mr. Commissioner, It is a privilege to present the report on the 20 concerns of citizens and companies
regarding the functioning of the single market precisely in this debate with Commissioner Barnier, in which the 20th anniversary of this market is signed.

A first word to thank the colleagues of all political groups and in particular to the reporters of Parecer and to the reporters Sombra for their constructive contributions and their positive attitude.
It was a pleasure to work with everyone and the report benefited a lot from our joint effort.

We know well and are proud that, over the past 20 years, the single market has been the engine of great economic and labor opportunities in Europe that have transformed the lives of European citizens and European companies.
Traveling, residing and working in the space of the Union are freedoms that are within the reach of all citizens of the 27 Member States.
For European consumers, the single market means more freedom of choice and lower prices.
For our companies, the single market means more business opportunities with access to 500 million consumers, which means more economic growth and more job creation.
To illustrate the progress that the Unique Market has made in Europe since its creation in 1992 until the beginning of the crisis
In 2008, just look at the 2.7 million jobs that were created and the 2.13% of the GDP growth.
Today, getting a telephone when you are traveling in Europe is 13% cheaper than in 2005.
People's freedom of movement has its most eloquent expression in the Erasmus program.
More than 2.5 million students benefited from this European Programme for Education and Mobility Exchange.
In the last five years, companies have also benefited from a 25% cut in administrative charges due to the UN market legislation.
But a question arises, is everything going well in the single market?
No, not everything works well.
The economic and financial crisis that affects us has had negative reflections on the functioning of this market.

Our citizens, in some countries, who are experiencing the drama of unemployment and are being confronted with austerity measures, have started to have a skeptical view of Europe and a negative view of the domestic market.
People still do not know or understand their rights enough, nor do they know where to find information or help.
On the other hand, many Member States delay unjustifiably the transposition of the European Directives and Legislations on the single market, thus harming its full potential.

In certain areas of life, things as simple as, for example, the reimbursement of medical expenses after a temporary stay in another country of the Union, the opening of a bank account by a student of the

the change of energy supplier, the transfer of pension reform, the recognition of qualifications and the registration of a vehicle in another Member State are still very complex, difficult or unruly acts.
It is important to answer these problems.
That was my concern as a reporter.
That is why the message written in the report is very clear. It is necessary more political will, much more political will of the Member States and European institutions
Council, especially Council and Commission, to govern better and together. It is necessary to regain the trust of people and companies and it is necessary to facilitate the exercise of their rights.

Finally, I would like to greet the European Commission, in person, by the presentation of the Act for Market 2, 12 Priority Act for New Growth, which marks, I am certain, a new stage for the future. Thank you very much.
Mrs. President, Mr. Commissioner Barnier and dear colleague Regina Bastos, my congratulations for your efforts, which have already been successful.
When Jacques Delors presided over the European Commission, the Union's single market was created in 1992.
Delors then synthesized the three basic principles of the single market. Competition that stimulates, cooperation that reinforces and solidarity that unites.
Twenty years have passed, the economic and financial crisis has brought the threat of national protectionism back and it became clear that the domestic market is not a finished work.

And the celebration of these 20 years must be used for a relaunch of the single market, with the concern of putting the market at the service of the citizen and not the citizen at the service of the market.
For this, priorities must be defined. I would like to talk about one priority in particular.
It is essential to have a common policy to produce and distribute energy at affordable prices to the consumer. With a high level of energy efficiency,
through the European energy market, served by cross-border infrastructures with the possibility of a community leverage of investment that represents added European value.
In energy, too, Mr. President, the common market will be judged.
One of the greatest achievements of the European Union, which surely represents one of the strongest pillars of the development of the Union, its member states and its regions.
However, in order to be effective and fair, it is necessary to accentuate its policies in the sense of equal opportunities for citizens and all regions, promoting the internal cohesion of the Union.

In this context, it is essential to recognize that we can only achieve greater development in our most remote regions, such as the ultra-parifere regions, through its greater insertion in the single market.

Regions like the Azores need to continue to increase their competitiveness, improving their competition conditions. But we will never be able to do it if we do not better solve our accessibility problems in the areas of transport.
We can achieve this through specific instruments that better respond to the problems caused by our detachment.
Therefore, we believe that the Commission should consider a specific program such as Pós-nei Transportes as an essential instrument for the insertion of these types of regions in the domestic market.
Thank you very much, Mr. President. I would like to start by saying thank you for this excellent debate.
It was a very constructive debate and it was a debate that demonstrated that the single market is really a great achievement of the European project.

I salute the presence of the Minister Mavroianis and his participation in this debate. I thank all colleagues for their constructive attitude, some of whom have a skeptical attitude, which is understandable.

and say thank you very much to Commissioner Barnier for his commitment and enthusiasm that he puts in the discussion of these issues, of these problems of the domestic market and of the political will to solve them.
We still have a lot to answer to citizens.
Citizens are dissatisfied, they are disappointed and they expect more from us, they expect more from the Council, they expect more from the Commission, they expect more from the Member States.
This balance is very useful, this 20 years balance is important, but as many said here, it is important to open the door to the future.
And the future perspective goes through many issues raised here and through many measures that have already been announced by the European Commission.
The digital market, the citizens' mobility, the reform of the EURES portal, the European energy market are examples
that we still have a long way to go in the future and that this path is very important and vital to respond to this time of crisis that we are living in.
Citizens are suffering, they are waiting for the politicians and the answers they can give to the adverse conditions they are suffering.
Therefore, it is important that the single market is one of the answers to the great challenge of competitiveness, employment and economic growth.
I am sure that all of us, after this celebration of 20 years, are more eager to give the answers that our citizens need. Thank you very much.

The GOSES report, along with the report we will elaborate on the annual growth prospects of the Union at the end of this year and which will be attended by the Council of the Spring, are two essential pieces of the so-called European semester.
This report addresses the recommendations made to each of the Member States by the Council under the Commission proposal. And these recommendations frame, as has just been said,
Six-Pack and the future Two-Pack, an extraordinarily strong body that reinforces European control over the economic and budget policy of member countries.

The balance between this control and autonomy and legitimacy at the national level is not easy to find. And it has fallen to a level of imposition, above all of discipline, and in the end it can even generate a serious package of sanctions.

Regarding the Tupac, I would like to comment briefly that it is important that the Council, which is absent today, gives a negotiating mandate to its negotiators, compatible with the ambition to quickly finish this package, this Tupac.

But more European coordination, going back to the subject, means a smaller control of the countries over their own destiny, which forces a subtle balance, but also an increased demand for the quality of the recommendations that are made to the countries in at least three or four dimensions.

First, it is important to ensure coherence between the goals of medium and long term, which include growth, employment and real convergence, and short-term recommendations, centered above all on discipline and nominal convergence. Secondly, it is necessary that there is coherence

with conclusions that should be taken from the analysis of macroeconomic imbalances, in particular, about the asymmetric impact of common policies and negative externalities, the spillover effects of some national policies on other countries.

Third, we need to make sure that there is a minimum line of social, economic and labor rights that cannot be exceeded by these recommendations. And finally, it is important that the quality of the recommendations is ensured according to the results achieved or that it is far from being the case so far.

I will finish now, Mr. President. I would like to thank Mr. Gozés for his spirit of collaboration and hope that he will take one more step in this spirit, in order to broaden the basis of consensus around his report and that this spirit will remain in what concerns the next
It is true, and it has been mentioned many times, that there are many things that we do not know about the extraction of X-rays.
But there are also many that we already know and it is good not to forget them.
We know, for example, that each extraction operation of X-Gas uses more than 19 million liters of drinking water, which can supply a year 1,000 European citizens in terms of their needs.

We also know that every extraction of X-Gas that is made, in each operation, is pumped to the ground 300 tons, sorry, tons, it can go up to 300 tons of chemicals and about 80% of which remain in the soil and do not leave there.

We also know that in each extraction of X-Gas, radioactive and heavy metals are released in the subsurface, which together with the evaporation of toxic waste resulting from the process, constitute an effective threat to public health.
This is a danger of contamination of the resources of drinking water and it is a contamination that is real and that is imminent.
Knowing this, we know that the extraction of X-Gas is an easy answer that only thinks about the immediate, the industry and the profit, ignoring the populations, the future and the environment.

But this is also Europe, which knows that water is an essential, vital and important resource, which knows how to protect citizens' health and which should protect it, which seeks to make agreements to avoid emissions and to propose energy efficiency because we know that environmental standards are important. Environmental standards and those of health.
So, when you don't know everything, being prudent is the minimum.
And you may even want to do it, but don't do it in our name or in the name of the citizens that are here to represent us.
Thank you very much, Mr. President. Dear colleagues, in fact, the last years have shown us how the monetary economic union did not resist the crisis,
We also showed that we had a European institutional architecture full of holes, in particular the institutional architecture of the Euro.
And that is why the report and proposal presented here are so far above in terms of the vision in relation to what is proposed by the Governments.

but also, as the reporter said, we are in a field of making political choices and that is why I would like to clarify the reasons why we have some problems and we will not be able to support this report.
First, it has to do with issues related to conditionality.

What we see and continue to have is a narrative in which there will only be solidarity between the different countries when everything is fulfilled in terms of stability and growth plan, in terms of intergovernmental agreement,
and a set of measures that do not impose anything else but massive doses of austerity in the peripheries and also a set of recessive measures that, as we have seen, are not working.
A second reason has to do with banking union.
The report presents the banking supervision mechanism very well, but it is so necessary that we cannot escape the essential. And the essential here is to escape as we continue to add

have agglomerated national systems, which means that we are all together in banking policy, we are all together in banking supervision, but we are all separated when something goes wrong and therefore the contributors will continue to pay.
And a third note has to do with the issue of common debt and the issuance of Eurobonds.
Here, once again, the possibility of common dividend emission is considered, but only when it is too late.

because we need the common debt, as it is now, not only when the deficits and excessive debts have been corrected, because with these policies that we are following they will never be corrected, on the contrary, they will be increasingly aggravated for the despair of an entire group of populations.

That is why I want to finish, Mr. President, by saying that, despite all the efforts, I think that we have here a very clear example that all together we could still get up, but divided, surely we will fall. And that is why it was important to go even further.
Mrs. Ferreira, please. There are always margins for progress, but for Portugal the support of the European Union in recent years has been fundamental.
Portugal has become a country whose competitiveness was based on cheap labor in a highly prepared and sophisticated labor country.
But when the country exports, it needs to have conditions for where?

And that's why it's important that some countries that have excedents open their doors to re-qualified exports from countries that started from a specialization profile that was absolutely unsustainable.

One last note to say that it is not possible that immigration is the solution, that the re-qualified workforce and where the support of the European Union was used is now lost through a massive export of the most qualified to the countries that have room to welcome them.
This is dramatic and completely makes our future unfeasible.

Thank you Mr. President. Small fishing should deserve special protection from the fishing community policy, not only because it promotes socio-economic cohesion and guarantees the support of many families, but also because it constitutes a fixation factor of these communities along coastal areas.
Its economic and social sustainability must be an objective, guaranteeing a different fishing regime that gives priority to access to resources,
allow the access to the nearby areas and protect the fishing rights of those who know the fishermen of those communities against the transferable fishing rights.
It is equally important for its sustainability to pay attention to the water access regime, especially in waters or regions with biogiogeographic pools.
with a reduced continental platform and low-abundant resources concentrated in submarine mounts and fishing banks that should have protected access.

In a context of liberalization and crisis, which weighs on the fragile regions, it should also be ensured that products from international trade meet the same requirements as the products that the Union imports.
